148416707.review:
When it comes to indie games, I appreciate how much can be done with minimal graphics. These pixel-based games have a charm that’s difficult to get right but really shines when they’re successful. Fez is such a game. As a puzzle platformer, the genre isn’t original. However, pivoting in 2-D planes to create a 3-D game is an ingenious way to expand the gameplay. Of course, this also makes it a little difficult to keep track of where you are and where you’re going. But with such relaxing visuals and sound design, spending extra time in this game isn’t a bad thing.

There are limitations to the pixelated style that make navigating the half-dozen worlds difficult to memorize. Sure, there are gimmicks in each world that define how you move around it, but knowing where to go to solve a larger puzzle within the game can be challenging. That there are so many branching paths that need backtracking to explore every corner of the Fez universe is both a blessing and a curse. There’s a lot to explore, but you’ll also be going through the same hub locations a lot as well.

With minimal plot, I appreciated the somewhat meta ending that played on how games from decades ago would behave. These games definitely inspired Fez and its visual style hearkens back to the time when you had to use pixelated graphics because that was all the computers could render. After getting to the credits, I had little desire to reach a 100% play-through. There were enough missing items that I knew where they were located, but did not know how to unlock them or get to them. Still, I enjoyed myself playing the amount of the game that I wanted to.

A retro-inspired puzzle platformer with a mind-bending gameplay mechanic, I give Fez 4.0 stars out of 5.

148282943.review:
[h1]The Gameplay: [/h1]
Platformer with an actual interesting Puzzle mechanic. You adjust the point of view  of the 2d platformer to make certain objects appear closer or in more detail than they were previously. It allows for a very unique platforming experience. Some of the puzzles will make you scratch your head, so it isn't for everyone.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
Something about a magical Fez, and I honestly don't remember enough to comment on it. IT wont be the reason you play this game though.

[h1]The Visuals:[/h1]
The art for this 16 bit  is very attractive and stylized. This was from a time when indie developers didn’t just slap shit on the steam store to try to make a quick buck.

[h1]The Sound:[/h1]
The sounds and music were appropriate for the game and gave it a nice and distinct feel. You'll probably not listen to it on your Spotify, but it'll carry you through the game without the need to play something over it.


[h1]The Experience:[/h1]
This was a good game that more or less set the bar for my expectations on 2d platformers that I would find from indie developers. Soon after many developers would let me down and just do a bunch of copy + paste low effort games and flood the market. I am surprised we don't have another game crash. This is certainly one of the good ones especially if you like this style of game.

148150436.review: A classic indie game. 3D spaces in a 2D environment is something really special. This game offers a new and unique perspective that kept me coming back for more. Surprisingly, I feel like I would still enjoy this game if it was just 2D. I'm not usually interested in 2D side-scrollers, so that's saying a lot. Lovely atmosphere and soundtrack. "Compass" is the BEST track. Makes me feel nostalgic and emotional. I love how the music changes when you go behind objects, it's a nice touch. The map is a little confusing, only because of how many branches there are. Still a cool design though. No fast travel, not counting small warp gates and secret doors, which kinda require some memorization. Not every game needs fast travel, but maybe some players don't want to spend time running back and forth. Also the game requires a bit of deciphering that the player has to figure out on their own, if they want to complete everything. There are many secrets. That can be fun for some people, and frustrating for others. Overall I love this game. It is unique and very chill. I have fun running around, collecting cubes. It's super satisfying. I'm a bit of a completionist so I did force myself to make it to 100%, but I couldn't be bothered to continue the bonus parts of the game.

If you're looking for a puzzle platformer with unique mechanics, slow-paced game play and a plot spicy enough to keep you going, I'd recommend something like Creaks instead.

146318506.review:
Fez is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece that takes players on a mind-bending journey through a world of intricately crafted puzzles and breathtaking visuals. This indie gem, developed by Polytron Corporation, is a true testament to the creativity and ingenuity of the gaming industry.

At its core, Fez is a platformer, but it's a platformer like no other. The game's standout feature is its unique 2D/3D mechanic, where you can rotate the 2D world to reveal hidden paths and solve puzzles. This simple yet ingenious gameplay mechanic turns every corner into an opportunity for discovery, and it's executed flawlessly. The transition from 2D to 3D and back is seamless, creating a sense of wonder and amazement that's hard to find in other titles.

The art style of Fez is a visual delight. It combines pixel art with a charming retro aesthetic, resulting in a world that's both nostalgic and fresh. The attention to detail is remarkable, with each area of the game feeling distinct and meticulously designed. The soundtrack, composed by Disasterpeace, is equally mesmerizing, enhancing the overall atmosphere and immersion.

What sets Fez apart is its dedication to exploration and discovery. There's no hand-holding here, which allows players to truly engage their problem-solving skills. The puzzles are challenging yet fair, rewarding players with a genuine sense of accomplishment when they conquer them. This sense of wonderment and curiosity is what makes Fez such a joy to play.

Fez isn't just a game; it's an experience. It encourages you to slow down, observe your surroundings, and appreciate the beauty of its world. It's a game that begs to be savored, not rushed through, and it's all the better for it.

146133054.review: Monument Valley meets Mensa. I did the deep-dive and got all achievements. Still working on deciphering the book. I'd say 2-3 of the puzzles are trolls, but they don't affect the ending. If you like puzzle games and can tolerate some janky platforming, this is a winner.

146097920.review: The ingenuity involved in this experience is ridiculous. It's already hard enough to imagine that, from a design perspective, the people who designed this game's levels had to understand how two-dimensional planes relate to one another in an overall three-dimensional space, but all the puzzles are so abstract and creative, yet make so much sense in hindsight (except for those mysteries that are still unknown--yes, still unknown--to this game's community). I've never played a game that rewards the player more for their ability to think than this one. Not only that, but the animation is fluid and charming; the music is calming, vivid, and atmospheric; the controls are sensible and reactive; and the world is intriguing and complicated. There's an entire linguistic, numeric, and glyph system to understand, and the game makes great use of its own design paradigms to progressively add challenge as you explore its giant, interconnected map (as such, a quicker and more straightforward transportation system would've been nice, but it's not like the lack thereof hindered my experience). There's no social commentary, and there are no messages. You don't actually have to understand anything substantial to play or even finish this game, and you'll still have fun playing it regardless. And if you choose to solve the intricacies of FEZ, it's still just a great experience and a captivating ode to the power of indie development.

146091812.review: Hidden behind the many layers are some of the most clever puzzles I've ever seen in a game.

146075939.review:
For a game comprised exclusively of right angles, it is ironically one of the most obtuse games I've played. The puzzles in the main path seldom exceed a difficulty level higher than what a typical child could achieve, yet on the other hand, the majority of the optional secrets are obscure beyond belief and sometimes even encroach into ARG territory. So you either A: win the game, and be left without the feeling of accomplishment due to the lack of hardship endured, never quite shaking off the feeling you're still in the tutorial. Or B: attempt some of the needlessly obscure secret "puzzles" and be left with a tremendous headache after bashing your head against some of the most frustrating and asinine puzzles you'll likely ever encounter.

Here are a few cherry picked examples of what you can expect from the plethora of secret puzzles: 
1): a QR code revealing the correct sequence of inputs. This isn't a puzzle; it's literally just getting your phone out and pressing the correct controls that it reveals. Though I suppose it's an admirable attempt at a meta puzzle, at least the first time around.
2): a QR code revealing the correct sequence of inputs. Ok, this isn't cool or interesting anymore.
3): a QR code. Ugh, did they really did just reuse the same dumb "puzzle" 3 times? But wait, there's more…
4): a QR code, but this time it's obstructed by some scaffolding from the level rendering it unscannable by conventional means. So I guess we're expected to reconstruct the QR code ourselves in some 3rd party program? Yeah, this is a bit too far for a video game for my taste. Perhaps this style of puzzle is right up your alley, but personally I can't imagine a less fun puzzle; I have no motivation to even attempt it. This is not what I was anticipating from a puzzle platformer game, especially considering the complete absence of any mention of this kinda stuff on the store page. 

There are many other secret puzzles, however a lot of the time they are far too confusing to even attempt or begin. On 2 or 3 occasions it's just been a small empty room completely devoid of, well, anything. Nothing to solve or look at or any hint towards anything, at all. For those I bet the solution is something like pressing the controls in a certain order as indicated by a sequence of random symbols in a random room in a random house in a random level but only if turned sideways and parsed through a base64 encoder backwards with the decryption key being the first letter of each person's name in the game credits. And based on what I've read from discussions and guides, I haven't even mentioned the worst of it; apparently there is an entire made-up alphabet and numerical system that you are required to learn in order to solve certain riddles. Yeah nah, if I'm going to go through the effort of learning a language I'd rather learn a real one with practical use as opposed to what essentially amounts to a glorified cipher. So, just skip the tortuous secrets? Unfortunately as I mentioned, ignoring the side stuff leads to a hollow and vapid game experience. This game is bafflingly designed to be an enjoyable experience exclusively for those with an IQ below 80, or above 150, or if you just love following guides. 

Even if you possess the intellect required for the secret puzzles, you still need the patience to endure agonizingly slow level transitions and clunky character movement that will result in many falls to your death. This is another huge issue I have; the lack of airborne maneuverability. If you miscalculate a jump, you're essentially screwed as your ability to control yourself in midair is negligible. Amusingly there's no punishment for dying; you literally respawn exactly where you were before, so the rigid movement doesn't result in a more difficult experience, it just adds to the tedium. And those doors, I cringe at the mere thought. Here we have the epitome of frustrating design: a game chockablock full of doors and gateways - about 3 average per level - and the time it takes to transition through one is 10 seconds. That might not sound like much, but each level is small in scale and will rarely take longer than a few minutes, so entering all those doors accounts for a lot of unnecessarily wasted time. With level design being non-linear and splitting off in all directions like it's a family tree from Dark, this naturally precipitates backtracking which would be fine in and of itself, if not for that superfluous transition every time you enter a level. By the end of the game, I had had enough and was just glad to have gotten this game over with. This is obviously not a good feeling to have when finishing a game, especially such a short one, hence my negative review. 

Admittedly, the core game mechanic is genius. This is a unique, innovative indie gem, and it might even be considered a masterpiece by some people. The visuals are bursting with life and energy, with even the smallest critters having delightful animations, despite the inherent low fidelity of pixelated graphics. Town areas in particular are incredible examples of pixel art scenery, with so much visual detail to soak in. My initial experience of the game was very positive, as the rotation mechanic was, and frankly still is, mind boggling. Unfortunately for me, several major flaws stuck out and soured my experience enough to dislike the game overall. My surprisingly good first impressions soon gave way to a mere 4/10 experience laden with frustration.

144287302.review:
No spoilers, no BS: simply the best puzzle-oriented platformer I've ever played. Not that I've played many, but I'm comfortable saying it might even be one of the best ever.

From a game design point of view, this game is pretty appreciable in a lot of ways. You can play it straight and quick, gathering the 32 cubes needed to reach the neutral ending within a matter of hours, and that experience in itself is great: the artstyle is simultaneously cutesy and endearingly simple, but also detailed and engaging. The level design is pretty brilliant, with various puzzles for hidden loot you can go on sprinkled in-between the various puzzles and puzzle-ish mechanics for level completion and progression. The controls are pretty solid, though I'll admit to some annoyance in that protagonist Gomez can feel a *little* slidy, as if on ice, at times, and the key mechanic at the center of this game -- rotation -- is done superbly well. It's not perfect, and can be a little buggy or irritating at times, but it's mostly not a problem and is utilized to awesome effect in level designs and puzzles.

Two of my favorite things about this game would be the soundtrack and the intricate world-building. Disasterpeace's soundtrack for this game is fantastic, with truly gorgeous, truly eerie, and truly BANGING chiptune songs serving as a perfectly fitting backdrop for this game. This game, too, has so much world-building and lore that never once gets addressed or explained to you in the (relatively minimal) dialogues throughout, instead appearing on chalkboards, obelisks, signs, posters, and what have you: it's there either as eye candy for the passive player, or, for the more dedicated puzzle enjoyers, the key to solving the more thought-provoking, complicated puzzles that are hidden, scattered, throughout this game's world, as well as understanding the story of this world and its peoples. 

My least favorite things are the backtracking and black holes. Backtracking becomes only truly necessary in two situations: first, if you don't play the game correctly and just skip over some cube bits or cubes, thinking "It'll be fineee" (it won't), and that's on you; second, if you want to do all the secrets and hidden puzzles. Some puzzles just cannot be done in the same moment you find them, and might require to go all over the world to read an alphabet explanation on some classroom in case you forgot it, or to go talk to some owls who are STUPIDLY far apart in terms of location, or you just have to travel a really long way from a warp gate to a puzzle room you missed earlier and it becomes tedious when you have to do that about ten times.

However, it would be less tedious if it weren't for the FUCKING black holes which become more frequent as you progress through the game -- I get that they have purposes, to hinder the player and have them find creative workarounds, but they completely forgot that second purpose in execution, because most of them will just show up and stay there until you exit and re-enter the level. These being the closest things to "antagonists" in this game makes me feel pretty comfortable in saying that they are some of the absolute worst antagonists of the most irritating nature in any game I've ever played; the last thing a puzzle-oriented game, which requires much patience, needs, is something to directly flip you off and tell you to come back later, because it makes that crucial patience wear thin FAST.

And, yeah, as for the puzzles? I first played through completed this game on Xbox almost a decade ago, after me and my oldest brother spent two years, on-and-off after schooldays, playing and decoding it together. Some things required a guide, but we got most of it -- make no mistake, this is a game that, if you want it to enjoy to the fullest, including the blissful satisfaction of solving some of its most mind-boggling puzzles, you're gonna need a notepad and pen and a fair bit of patience, as me and my brother did. But man oh man, solving those puzzles and coming to the point where, even at a young-ish age, I could read them like a second language felt awesome.

This game strikes a fine, fine balance between being a memorable treat of a playthrough for a casual gamer and a gourmet meal for a  ̶t̶o̶t̶a̶l̶ ̶n̶e̶r̶d̶  truly dedicated gamer. But, seriously, screw those black holes.

I give Fez a score of 8 "WHAT'S THE FUCKING SOLUTION GODDAMNIT"s out of 10 and my own personal "GODDAMNIT I HAVE TO GO ALL THE WAY BACK THERE AGAIN???" badge of approval.

144137715.review:
Beautiful, atmospheric however comvoluted in a bad way

[h1]Story[/h1]

Not much of a story, it starts at a small island town, a certain characters says something is gonna happen and BAM! go find some cubes either the world will colapse.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

It is quite simple, few mechanics and not enough to analize here regarding this aspect; its gameplay was a novelty at the time it came out because of the 2D/3D gimmick that makes the game a cool experience, giving a certain perspective of the stages and world is great, it feels fresh and original. 

There are lots of puzzles and secrets all over the different stages, some easy some extremely difficult, busting your head is a must.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Fez is a beautifully crafted game, lots of love was poured into the creation of the world, its pixel art and direction makes it one of a kind and I dare to say it inspired a whole new series of games that took this idea and implemented it for other titles. Great graphics, not much to add.

[h1]Music and Sound[/h1]

The music is very atmospheric and mellow while the sound effects are obviously a la 16-bits style. Good.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

Fez for the most part is interesting and it drives you to play it, however no matter how pretty it looks; navigation, gameplay and most importantly the puzzles are a total disaster in my opinion, if you manage to figure them out and solve these puzzles, I commend you, you are the best; in my case I thought the game was quite easy and enjoyable, as soon as I found my first puzzles I had no idea how to solve them, everything is cryptic, there is not much of a guideline as to how to solve them: some of them are straightforward and the catch lies in front of us, the rest of them, well, good luck solving them.

Looking for any piece of information online to solve puzzles was the way to go for me, sincerely how people manage to read between the uncanny lines is a mystery to me. I mean, I see no problem asking online or looking for an answer to a question or doubt when it comes to games, but do we really need to check online to solve every puzzle? is that how this game is supposed to be played? I'm puzzled.

Not only the puzzles are a chore to solve, the navigation is a drag and not good in the long run, coming and going is just boring, confusing and simply badly designed considering that every new zone has sub zones those sub zones have more of them, I really wish I would have liked the game more than I did, it just isn't for me.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

It certainly had an impact and I can see that on the reviews praise the game and its concept, for me it just did not cut it, convoluted, boring, repetitive, cryptic and unclear. I wish I could give it a neutral review, but alas that is not possible.

9.5/10
Fez is a 2D game with a 3D world. The thing that made Fez special from other side-scrolling platformer games is that you can change the viewing angle by 90 degrees and this mechanic allows you to see the game world from four different directions. This unique mechanic is so important in Fez because most of the puzzles solve by using this mechanic. But this special mechanic is not make Fez a must-play game. Everything in Fez like art design, music, level design and specially puzzles are doing their job perfect and show us that why Fez deserves to be called a masterpiece.
+:
Superb level design
Gameplay based on exploring, changing the view angle and good platforming
Beautiful pixel art with good music
Variety of puzzles and challenging side puzzles which are help the game to not get repetitive
Checkpoints in good positions that prevent the game from getting too hard
-:
Sometimes sounds and music are annoying

143122770.review:
Fez is a fun little game with interesting platforming mechanics and some fun puzzles... if your goal is just to complete the main story. The graphics and music are excellent, dialogue is minimal, allowing you to focus on the gameplay, and what story you will see is weird enough to be oddly compelling.

If your goal is to go above and beyond simply completing the main quest, the puzzles become far too cryptic for my liking. Many of these optional puzzles require decoding the strange symbols seen throughout the game. After looking at a guide to see how this was supposed to be done... yeah, I doubt many people will figure these ones out on their own. If you don't enjoy using guides, chances are you will not enjoy going after every last hidden item. Some of the puzzles felt similar to TUNIC, so fans of that game's puzzles will likely enjoy some of these.

The best part of a puzzle game is that moment where everything clicks and you finally find the solution, and Fez has plenty of moments just like this that you're sure to encounter on your journey. The worst feeling in a puzzle game is when you say 'screw it' and check a guide, which you will have to do in order to obtain 100% completion, at which point you're barely playing the game!

Overall, I really enjoyed my time with the main quest in this game and would highly recommend giving it a go if you haven't yet. Just consider not going for 100% unless you're the type of person who doesn't mind checking a walkthrough at a few points.

140084721.review:
Rotating the 2d world is a nice twist on these kind of 2d-pixel-platformers. But it needs something more than that and it doesn't really have it. And the rotation mechanic never really made me feel like I was clever for solving some puzzle. It was mostly -- go as far as you can. Get stuck. Rotate the world three times looking for other paths forward. You're rarely looking more than one or two steps ahead with the rotation. Pretty quickly -- somewhere between 1 and 2 hours -- it began to feel a bit too same-y.

Plot is rarely a strong point in this type of game (who is playing Mario for the plot) but it basically non-existent here. You need to collect cubes to save the world.

The individual level design is....fine. It is mostly variations on "climb the tower", as you can see from the videos on the store page. But I found the over-world design very confusing to follow where I was, where this warp gate had taken me to, and how to get back to where I needed to be next. It has a very non-Euclidean kind of geometry where sometimes you step through a door and it teleports you to a different stage on the level, sometimes it is just a room you can explore, and sometimes it teleports you to another level entirely. And that kind of killed the vibe a bit for me. Instead of feeling like I was exploring I mostly felt like I was just lost.

I collected 11 of the 32 cubes before I had my fill of the game. I gather from other reviews that there's an abrupt shift to some kind of code-solving puzzle but I didn't make it that far before dropping the game. That's not the kind of puzzle I particularly enjoy anyway.

140082326.review:
100% Review

FEZ is a mind-blowing platformer puzzle game that kept me intrigued the whole way through. Despite it's world map being dauntingly huge, I managed to find worth in exploring it rather than being intimidated by it. The perspective-changing mechanic was trippy, unique, and was used it increasingly clever ways throughout the game. But how could I review the game without talking about the puzzles? Hints leading towards rewards are littered everywhere in FEZ, and while it does have 75+ collectibles, I feel the game's length made it so the process of collecting all of them doesn't overstay it's welcome. The puzzles were unique and went beyond what I could've thought of, such as decoding parts of the map, scanning QR codes, using context clues, and much more to reveal secrets. Though it's not without mention that some of the puzzles are downright unsolvable on your own; The game's show-not-tell philosophy was quite interesting, but I think they took it too far. While I did notice some bugs, they were few and far between. Overall, FEZ was a very enjoyable experience that I highly recommend.

139822605.review:
On both its surface and deeper levels, Fez is wonderful. 

The pixel/voxel art of each world is incredible, with each world's visuals completely blowing me away. Disasterpeace's soundtrack for Fez is outstanding, perfectly matching and enhancing the tone of each environment. The core gameplay's simplicity allow you to have fun moving around and manipulating space while still being able to take everything in.

The puzzles you'll find when looking deeper into Fez are challenging but incredibly rewarding. The rich depth of each environment lets you slowly piece together solutions to puzzles while giving you a better understanding of the story. I will never look at Tetris nor owls the same way ever again.

The game does have a few bugs which can affect your immersion at certain parts, but generally it's pretty seamless.

139656023.review:
FEZ: A Puzzle Platformer with an Eccentric Developer

Review:
FEZ is a puzzle platformer that offers a unique and mind-bending experience, earning a respectable 4/5 rating from me. It's a game that showcases creative level design, intriguing puzzles, and a distinctive art style. However, it's impossible to talk about FEZ without acknowledging the eccentric and controversial nature of its developer, which has garnered mixed opinions within the gaming community.

In terms of gameplay, FEZ excels in providing a fresh take on the platforming genre. The central mechanic revolves around rotating the 2D world to reveal hidden paths and solve puzzles. This unique twist adds depth and complexity to the gameplay, challenging players to think in unconventional ways. Exploring the intricately designed levels and uncovering secrets is an absolute delight.

Visually, FEZ stands out with its pixelated art style, reminiscent of classic 8-bit games. The vibrant colors and charming retro aesthetics create a nostalgic atmosphere that adds to the game's charm. The soundtrack also deserves praise, with its soothing melodies that perfectly complement the serene and mysterious ambiance of the game.

However, it's important to address the controversy surrounding the developer, Phil Fish. While his creative vision brought us the unique experience of FEZ, his public persona has been divisive. Some may find his outspoken nature and controversial remarks off-putting, which has led to a divided perception of the game within the gaming community. It's worth noting that personal opinions about the developer should not overshadow the merits of the game itself.

Despite the eccentricities of its creator, FEZ remains an engaging and enjoyable puzzle platformer. It challenges players with its clever puzzles, rewards exploration, and immerses them in a visually captivating world. If you're a fan of puzzle games and appreciate unique gameplay mechanics, FEZ is definitely worth a try.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐
A Puzzle Platformer with an Unconventional Developer: FEZ offers a mind-bending experience with its innovative gameplay and charming pixel art style. While the controversy surrounding the developer may have influenced public opinion, the game itself is deserving of a solid 4/5 rating.

139653526.review: A very innovative platformer with intricate puzzles. I highly recommend it.

139179802.review:
This game has great music. The puzzles are cryptic, and you won't have a linear path to guide you. The platforming aspect is secondary. You will have to exlpore and solve the puzzles, and enjoy the scenery.

The main mechanic of switching between the four 2D perspectives is great. Once I started getting used to it, I felt like I was seeing reality differently! But, it's not really like you have to think to advance. It's more of a "getting used to" thing than a "understand through thinking" thing. You just turn until you get the right platform next to you so you can jump further. Maybe if there had been a sequel, it could have expanded on the concept so that it would make it puzzly and not just turning perspectives until you get the right one. The mechanics would have to be different I think.

ADVICE:
Don't play with a guide!
Playing with a guide will take away most  of the point in experiencing this game. Go slowly at it, and be observant. If you get stuck, go explore other places.

You can get to the end without solving every puzzle: you just need to obtain 32 of the "Cubes" (collectibles you have to find) out the 64 total. 
Then, to complete the harder puzzles left and get the collectibles remaining, you can ask for hints and help.

I think it's the best way to enjoy this game.

139173253.review: FEZ is one of those games that I'd heard a lot about and thought I *knew* a lot about up until I watched a very spoiler-free speedrun last year and realized I actually didn't know anything about this game. I bought it on a whim, sat down with it for a couple of hours the first night, and then couldn't stop thinking about it. The mechanics are fluid and play off one another in a way that I love; the environments are gorgeous, the music even more so; and I came away from the ending of this game thinking about games that have followed in this one's footsteps in the 10+ years since its release, and how much appreciation I have for those games, and for this game. I'd say that FEZ walked so that games like Tunic and Inscryption could run, but truly, this game was already running. 10/10 and I can't wait to come around in a year and play it again.

134693773.review:
Es la segunda vez que arranco este juego, la primera vez no fui capaz de terminarlo cuando lo jugué en PC, no se si porque no terminé de entender como funcionaba el mapa, por falta de tiempo o falta de concentración al jugar, ya que tiene su complejidad y recuerdo que a veces acababa de jugar con algo de dolor de cabeza, pero está vez he tenido la oportunidad de jugarlo en PSVITA y de acabarlo.

Ya la primera vez que jugué noté que era un juego muy especial y que juega muy bien con la perspectiva bidimensional que realmente sucede en un entorno tridimensional (de hecho me encanta el añadido de las gafas de sol al rejugarlo, que te permiten tener una visión en primera persona de lo que ve nuestro protagonista, aunque también te quedas con ganas de poder desplazarte de esa forma, sin embargo por la propia jugabilidad del título esto sería imposible ya que hay lugares que si no fuera por los truquillos de perspectiva sería imposible de llegar). Además el asunto de la jugabilidad basada en la perspectiva lo integran de varias formas dentro de la historia, ya que los habitantes de la aldea inicial no creen en esa tercera dimensión, ni en lo que es un cubo que es precisamente los objetos que nos dedicamos a recoger durante la aventura. El objetivo secundario de coleccionar anticubos si que se vuelve algo pesado al estar tan ocultos que necesitas si o si una guía para encontrarlos. La gran mayoría de los secretos más ocultos es realizar una combinación de botones en una ubicación específica, lo cual es muy difícil de intuir.

Es una lástima que su desarrollador Phil Fish acabara harto de la industria y terminara por cancelar la secuela, Fez 2, ya que he acabado con ganas de ver cómo podría continuar, o ver qué juegos de perspectiva y puzzles se podrían desarrollar en entornos más amplios o variados.

Muy recomendado.

FEZ is a masterpiece of indie game development that has left a lasting impression on me to this day. As one of the first indie games I ever played, it introduced me to a world of creative, innovative gameplay and immersive storytelling.

Despite the fact that there has been no news of a sequel, I still hold out hope that one day Phil Fish might change his mind. However, even if that never happens, I am grateful to him for creating such an unforgettable game that holds a special place in my heart.

Almost a decade old, and still holds up graphically:
- Scales amazingly to big-screen 4k
- Supports 120Hz+
- Fluid animations, tight enough controls, nice variation in graphical style between different stages... this has everything you would want from a platformer.

Additionally, there is a surprisingly low amount of frustration because dying doesn't throw you back to beginning. The character is instantly re-spawned to the spot where they fell. That being said, after opening many levels and biomes (?), travelling/teleportation starts to get quite confusing and even tedious at times and this will probably prevent me from completing the game. Save state is at 70%+, so I think I still got a reasonable impression of what this old gem has to offer.

Very few modern puzzle platformers can match FEZ:s elegance and quality. Now I see why this was, and continues to be, the benchmark.

133516619.review:
In Fez, you play as Gomez. Gomez is a 2D creature living in a 2D world.
When it discovers the 3rd dimension, you must maneuver this 3D diemnsion using 2D spaces to solve puzzles to try and save the universe.


[u]Gameplay: 7/10[/u]

Gameplay is... alright. It depends on how you deep you want to take the game. There are three "tiers" of difficulty or puzzles.
An easy tier, a very difficult and obscure tier, and then an impossible tier.
The easy tier is... well... easy, and is more of a platformer where you collect things.
The difficult tier, is much more of a difficult code-cracking puzzle game. Where you will likely need to end up looking up a guide to solve some challenges.
The impossible tier... well, hasn't been beaten yet. If it [i]can[/i] be beaten.

In short, the best experience is likely trying to solve 80% of the puzzles in the difficult tier and all the "puzzles" in the easy tier without a guide.
This way you can experience the unique challenges the game presents, and enjoy the game's exploration without getting too bogged down by the obscure stuff.


[u]Story, World and Characters: 5/10[/u]

The story is fairly basic and overall the world is very vague. There is no backstory to your character, and very little explanation to the ideas presented about the world's history.
This doesn't fit the game poorly in my opinion, as long as you don't go in expecting a great story.


[u]Graphics, Audio and Technical Execution: 8/10[/u]
The graphics are the beautiful with the minimalistic pixel art aesthetic really matching the game and was pulled off very well.
As for the music and sound effects, they are done well. Also, the bugs I did encounter were not too game-breaking. Apart from a crash, which wasted about 60 seconds of my time.


[u]Replayability, Value for Money and Extra Content: 5/10[/u]

I did a lot of puzzles without a guide, and 100% the game. If you 100% the game, you will have incredible value for money.
As for replayability, I don't really see it. Once you know how a puzzle is solved, you probably won't forget and I don't see myself replaying this game any time soon.
There is basically no extra content, excluding the impossible puzzles which don't count.


[u]Innovation, Impact and Technical Execution: 7/10[/u]

I feel like, the game innovated a lot on its puzzle genre with loads of fresh and new puzzles and ideas.
The game runs well, but has very poor controls on PC. 


[u]Overall - [b]64/100[/b] - "Reality is perception. Perception is subjective."[/u]

This a great little game, that you will likely enjoy despite the flaws it has. The way it deals with mystery and discovery is great.
However, there is still the tedium of travelling from one spot to another spot and the obscurity of some puzzles.
Overall, a great little adventure but one I wouldn't replay.

133428942.review: Playing this game made me go slightly insane, especially since there are two controls for "left" and "right", one of which rotates the level, and one moves Gomez. 133191134.review:
Fez completely passed me by when it came out in 2013 due to far too little coverage in the gaming press; so only played it last year after seeing the famous documentary it was in.

Fez has quickly become one of my favourite games of all time: it is truly a masterpiece.  Put simply, it is a real joy to play, with excellent pixel-art and animations, a fantastic soundtrack and a great variety of different levels and puzzles.  Many of the environments are absolutely beautiful and truly evoke a perfect nostalgia of the 8- and 16-bit eras.  The rotatable, 3D level design is genius and the litany of collectables and tough puzzles will keep you searching for a great many hours, including an foreign alphabet and numeric system to decode.

While there isn't much of a storyline, that did not bother me much; although it would have been a nice addition.  My only complaint is that a few of the puzzles are just too difficult for 99.9% of people to get without resorting to guides.  I'm nearly 30-hours in and still have 3 or 4 I haven't figured out yet, but won't resort to cheating with guides.

If you like the art style in the screenshots just buy it, as it is a steal at the current price and there is a lot to love about it.

132480875.review:
Fez is a creative twist on a puzzle platformer, that offers more depth and complexity to it's collect-a-thon the more you go in. From shifting perspectives, a secret alphabet, and even changing your system time, Fez continually offers new puzzles to crack right up until the very end. The story is fascinating but not intrusive and the endings will leave you stunned and puzzled, all topped off with the brilliant work of disasterpiece. If you do want to go for 100% (listed as 212% in game), don't feel guilty for using a guide. While most puzzles are fair, many require backtracking with knowledge you find later in the game, and there are a few I can recall that were a little frustrating, but I would still recommend a blind run so it doesn't feel like a to-do list. 
Overall, one of my favorite indie titles. 9.5 out of ten.

130924228.review:
FEZ is a two-dimensional side-scroller platformer with a three-dimensional twist. Players can use a set of keys to view the current screen from another quarter-turn to the left or the right. In addition to arrow keys for movement and spacebar for jump, there is also a set of keys to rotate the level left or right (AD) and another set keys to look around (IJKL). I got these mixed up sometimes (and sometimes used the wrong ones for IJKL due to touch-typing and moving back and forth from the arrow keys). I think my confusion only really happened when trying to use all three key sets at the same time. On the whole I think the original bindings were good.

The story is that you play as Gomez, a citizen of Village who must restore its balance by reassembling the hexahedron by collecting 32 cubes. The cubes may be broken down further into shards. [spoiler]Also, anti-cubes may count toward this tally.[/spoiler] There is falling damage, but the game quickly and seamlessly resets you to the last solid ground you had touched. The frequent auto-saves make it easier to chip away at this game little by little.

There are probably about 100 rooms all told, with occasional warp points and/or wormholes to shortcut navigating through them -- or in some cases, out of them, if it was difficult to reach a specific place in a room. The in-game map is very helpful for figuring out what's left to do and how to get there. Although it may be useful to know not to "sweat it" if you can't complete a room right away. [spoiler]Sometimes you need items from other rooms.[/spoiler] While movement through rooms is mostly linear, players have a lot of freedom to choose which room to go to; however, because puzzles generally felt like they had only one solution, I think I would count this game as mostly closed-world.

I'm not very familiar with retro arcade games, but in terms of feel, FEZ does seem to be a nod to (and maybe inspired/influenced by) them. Level design, from the perspectives of art and puzzle-solving, is excellent! The music and sound effects are pleasant and complement the throwback feel of the game. No voice acting, all game dialogue is text-based. Gameplay is pretty solid. The few glitches I encountered were visual. [spoiler](And a few weren't even bugs -- I later realized the game was "supposed to do that"!)[/spoiler] I don't remember how I found this. Maybe through the Steam store. Then again, I may have seen friends playing it. 

I had played halfway through FEZ a few years ago. I feel like I understood the game (mechanics, especially) better this time around. Specifically, I found it helpful to [spoiler]think of each rotated level as its own (or new) room[/spoiler]. The rotations I felt sometimes had some counter-intuitive effects, but once I got a handle on them, puzzles were challenging and entertaining. So due to getting used to how the game world behaves, I would say there's a little bit of a learning curve with this game. I expected this game to take somewhere between 6 to 12 hours to play. A Time Played clock associated with my save slot in the game marked me as taking 6.5 hours. 

FEZ is a nice, quick mind-stretching puzzle game with unique game mechanics and a new take on a classic theme. I would pull this one out again to get the rest of the achievements (I'm at about 50% right now) and collectibles.

130283216.review:
Fez is a good puzzle-platformer. Plenty of people agree with me about this fact. But there's more to it than that:

Aesthetically, I think this whole game hangs together really nicely - the art-style and Disasterpiece's soundtrack combined are undoubtedly gorgeous. I enjoyed the platforming elements immensely; the changing-perspective-to-get-from-A-to-B mechanic was really well executed and didn't get boring.

As a straight-up puzzler, the game was fairly weak. Granted, you could pretty much ignore much of it (as I did) and still get to the credits. But this weakness really doesn't make me want to 100% this game (plus navigating the entire World isn't that great, either). The esoteric substitution cypher isn't great; I know what the solution is after looking it up after the fact, but I wouldn't know where I'd find this in the game.  And God help you if you're not a native English speaker familiar with pangrams.

Some of the puzzles are okay, but others are pretty mean. The Bell puzzle, in my opinion, is terrible; it relies upon solving the substitution cypher to ring the faces of the bell a number of times. But the bell chimes are tuned to allow the Westminster Chimes to be played; having the Westminster Chimes be the answer would have been a far better and more intuitive solution to this puzzle.

The fact you can skip over anything you find rubbish and be assured you can still beat the game is a positive, but harly a ringing endorsement for the game as a whole.

I might drop back into this game at some point. But the strength of the puzzles and navigation aren't ever going to bait me into wanting 100%. 

Buy this game on sale and have fun getting to the credits. It's worth that, for sure. But that's gonna be about it, I reckon.

Coming back to post a review after finishing another game with some strong similarities in puzzles.

While I spent time getting 100% in this, I can't say I'd recommend it now. Lets start with the good....

The good: 

Beautiful music, stellar art design, and a really cool central game mechanic.

The Bad/Ugly: 

While most of the puzzles have fun designs, getting to 100% is super obtuse and requires you translate an in game language based on very vague hints. I can admire it, but at the same time it feels like someone writing their own DnD campaign and thinking they made the best fun puzzles for their own home brew dungeon, but when it comes to actually putting players through it you'll find that people may think different than you do, and what breadcrumbs you think you may be dropping are completely missed by the party.

If you're a completionist you'll absolutely need a guide. And unfortunately for a puzzle centric game, I feel like is a bad thing. Its one thing to need one for a type of puzzle you're horrible at, but another thing to need one for the core puzzle underlying everything.

If this is cheap on sale, go for it...if not something like Tunic or Outerwilds are better experiences.

from appearance and concept alone, i understand why this game may not look appealing, or even fun to most people. even as someone who likes the art style and perspective-shifting concept, the map is extremely vast and major areas are easy to miss. the platforming does not change throughout the entire game either. so, for most people, it just seems like another generic indie collectathon platformer, with an a**hole creator for those who know him. i think what people do not understand is that the platforming actually isn't the core focus of this game. people get confused by the ending, and forget about the game without bothering to check out new game+. it's still a collectathon in nature, but less a collectathon platformer and more of a collectathon puzzle game, each puzzle being more absurd and special than one might realize.

for those who know about outer wilds, this game feels like a more extreme version of that, and is also excruciatingly hard to describe to people and sell them on it. this game uses platforming as a sort of avenue for exploration of a world filled with mystery and puzzles. (sidenote: outer wilds may not be a platformer, but "controls/gameplay used as an avenue for another goal" is still a theme which heavily applies to both games.) also, unlike outer wilds, it's not necessarily centered around a story that can be fully solved in the first place, which is completely ok -- you can still get a majority of the way there, and complete even new game+ without knowing everything. the entire point of this game, at least, in my opinion, is that not everything is meant to be solved, and you can find peace within not knowing everything. even with this in mind, this game has a lot of mystery worth checking out. i recommend playing with another person to help guide you or figure things out, but do not make them tell you what to do. 

the only case in which you need to be told what to do is if you're looking to collect the red cubes, all of which aren't necessary to beat new game+, aren't required for any of the achievements, and are practically impossible to solve on your own. they're a bonus.

129147548.review:
This is a good game. It has really unique movement -- a quick elevator pitch is that it's a 2d platformer in a 3d world. It also has a really cool environment and some fun lore, and makes great use of all these things.
The first half of this game is primarily a collectathon, which is probably the best part, since it gives you an excuse to explore the environment and make use of the puzzling movement options. 
Around when you roll credits, it becomes about going back to old areas and solving puzzles. these puzzles vary, but tend to involve careful observation and figuring out what things mean. This part is imperfect; there are some puzzles that make this game basically impossible to 100% without outside help, and a few that are just QR codes. It's very easy to wander around without making any progress in this section, which often led me to quit, typically for months. When I did make progress though, it felt great.
One last thing to note is that there are several groups of these later puzzles that are solved basically the same; this makes breakthroughs more impactful but also means less puzzle overall.

127302465.review:
FEZ is a great game that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys 2D Puzzle-Platformers.  The main mechanic of the game is the ability to change your perspective of the world around you, which is crucial to platforming and puzzle solving. Your main goal in FEZ is to collect the 32 cubes, a majority of which are broken into smaller pieces you need 8 of to combine into a cube. Most of the cubes are gotten from platforming and exploration.

There is another side of this game, which is what some find to be the "real game." This side is the 32 anticubes. Every anticube has some sort of puzzle attached to it. Some are much harder than others. Most of these anticubes make up my favorite portion of this game, which is the "meta" puzzles. This includes things such as QR Codes, translating a new language, etc.

Although I loved this game, I think it has some major flaws. These flaws aren't big enough for me not to recommend it, but they do exist.

The first flaws come from learning the language. While I had no trouble learning the language, it requires you to know a very specific english phrase, which if you don't speak english is almost impossible for you to figure out. My issue is with the puzzle for figuring out the number translations. I feel like this could have been explained better, as the puzzle for figuring out how to read numbers is complicated and explained poorly.

The second flaws come from the secret "red cube" collectibles. There are three of them, and I think all three puzzles to solve them are terrible. I'm going to explain my issues without spoilers, so people who have played know what I'm talking about and people who haven't don't. I would have never figured out any of these solutions, and resorted to a guide for all of them. The red star puzzle has a solution that makes me think that I would have never gotten it if I was left in a room for thousands of years, as nothing even hints as to what your supposed to do for the solution. The solution to the security room puzzle is just bad in my opinion, and the black pillar puzzle solution is so obscure that I haven't even found an answer online as to how your supposed to figure out the second code.

All in all, FEZ is a great game with some flaws in the later puzzles. I highly recommend.

123900980.review:
I remember when I first heard of Fez it was touted as one of the best puzzle/platformers out there. It's really more of a platformer with light puzzle elements. I really enjoyed the puzzle elements but I wish they took more advantage of them. It felt like more of an exploration game.

That being said, it was still an enjoyable exploration game. It was cool spinning the world in a 3D perspective to traverse it in 2D. It reminded me a bit of Carl Sagan's Flat Land theory about a possible fourth dimension. The puzzles themselves didn't really feel mind bending but trying to traverse the world was. The world map was really confusing to read. Fortunately each "level" is very small and can be traversed in just a couple minutes each. 

My one major complaint is the jumping. Jumping feels weird, there's a strange momentum that feels slow. Sometimes when you climb onto a platform, you have to give your character a second to get situation before he jumps. If you try to jump immediately, it just won't work and you'll run off the platform. If you fall from a tall height, you'll die an instantly respawn where you fell from. Generally speaking, when you run into those cases where you accidentally run off a platform instead of jumping, it'll be from a height great enough to die and respawn but it still makes it feel a bit tedious.

This is still an enjoyable, albeit more casual, "puzzle/platformer." Indie titles like this always age gracefully, don't let the release date fool you. This will still be worth your time for a long time to come.

123169859.review:
Replayed after ~10 years. The main mechanic of flipping between 2D dimensions still holds up and the puzzles are enjoyable. Its a fun little time capsule into the beginning of the indie boom, with some level design that almost feels a bit cliché now, whilst still totally working as it should. Difficulty-wise it builds nicely, with some very meta puzzles strewn in that are very clever. The design is not linear, so you will be jumping back and forth between sections you've already been in, but suddenly realize hidden puzzles you hadn't noticed before. Fez feels very indie, in the best of ways.

As with my first playthrough, I couldn't be bothered to 100% it (or in-game, it's registered more like 201.1% or something) - but going in I knew the difficulty and slight tediousness of the very last puzzles and knew it was totally okay to choose not to continue playing. The game is "beat" at 50%, so I don't feel like I'm missing a huge part by not getting the "good" ending.

121387412.review:
Uno de los videojuegos que puso de moda el término "indie", y sin duda con todo el mérito que puede tener. La jugabilidad del juego es tremendamente buena y un concepto nunca visto antes, o al menos no con esta calidad.
Básicamente, jugamos con la perspectiva 3D del escenario para, rotándolos de 90º en 90º, hacer una suerte de "escalera de Penrose" en dos dimensiones.
La estética del juego, aunque es pixel art, está muy bien recreado, ya que realmente son entornos en 3D simulando que son 2D. Además tiene unas animaciones del personaje bastante buenas.
El esquema del juego se basa en una especie de metroidvania donde tendremos que ir desbloqueando diferentes puertas con unos cubos que vamos encontrando por el mapeado. 
No es un juego largo, y es perfecto paran jugar en Steam Deck, entre otras cosas por su bajo consumo de batería. 
Mención especial a la locura que ha hecho este desarrollador con la cantidad de secretos secundarios que tiene el juego, que son directamente una locura, recomiendo ver algún vídeo de YouTube hablando del tema porque os va a volar la cabeza. La de horas que tiene que haber estado diseñando estas cosas, que además casi nadie va a ver. 

Sin duda un imprescindible, y una verdadera lástima que este hombre acabase quemado y se alejase de hacer más videojuegos.

119881191.review:
By the time I 'beat' Fez, I realised I was playing two games. The first is a puzzle-platformer that uses 2D planes in a 3D world in a fun and challenging way to force you to think about more than what you're just seeing. The second is an esoteric, often-times seemingly cryptic puzzle game that requires some thought removed from the game itself to solve.

Of these two games, I like the first, but dislike the second. By-and-large, you can see the credits roll without needing to engage too much with the second. The problem I found, however, was that as you were playing through the first game it started giving way to the second. By the time I was almost at the credits, I was finding it more and more difficult to find the part of the game I enjoyed. So why the recommendation?

What this first part offers is a rhythm where you can really build up a momentum to moving around and finding this or that, or giving you the time and space to work out what's being asked of you and to mess around until you get the reward. With an inviting aesthetic and a suitable soundtrack, this is Fez at its best. Sure, some of the asks do get more challenging, but they're often met with the satisfaction of realising what you should be doing, or that moment of idiocy you feel when you realise the simplicity of the solution compared to your muddling through. All these aspects that make a puzzle enjoyable.

You get hints even fairly on though that this second game is going to take over sooner or later. Even before then, maybe you find the playable Gomez a bit sluggish in movement, a bit uncertain of your jumping from platform to platform. I got used to it, but I do wish it was a little faster and confident. You also have to reckon with general map traversal which I never found easy, almost as if I was fighting the map as much as I was the puzzles. Doors lead you all over the place, some jumping from one area to a distant other, but the lack of any sort of minimap, despite a smart preview of where a door leads if you've already been in, makes the greater scale of the world unnecessarily frustrating to navigate. The large pause-menu map works, but it can be clunky and breaks the pacing.

These issues can be put to the side, as frustrating as they are, with how enjoyable the puzzles are, but as you start having to skip rooms because you have no clue what you're supposed to be doing, or have to come back later when you work out what the game is telling you to do in its own language it wants you to decipher, as well as getting lost or going in loops, the early enjoyment begins to recede. If I played much longer, I think I would've turned on the game and started to dislike it.

Overall, there's some brilliant puzzles in here that are genuinely satisfying to solve and moving around a world that has a greater scale than what you can initially see is fantastic, but the longer it went on the more my enjoyment waned. At a certain point I had my fill, not being encouraged to do the rest of what the game was, I believe, unfairly asking of me.

119612275.review:
The game is good in terms of solving puzzles, art style, and music. The atmosphere was also very well done in creating the mood.

The puzzles were very well crafted.

The game features a rotation mechnic, where you rotate "the world" for a different view of the land. This is mixed with 2D and 3D things. Where a 2D object will disappear depending on the angle. Things will reveal themselves from a different angle of rotation. The rotation is automatic, whereas you push the rotate button and it rotates 90 degrees.

The only negative thing I have to say, is that the game quickly devolved into "jump up to a place and rotate 4+ times before moving on and quickly repeat a short distance away". You do this the entire game.
If you don't, you will be missing out on secrets, easter eggs, solutions to puzzles, puzzles, collectibles, and so on. This could be a turn off. If there were markers to show you where puzzles are, then you begin to solve it. This will cut down on the constant rotation everywhere you go.
Finding the puzzle I'm sure will be part of the "exploration" people will argue. Yes, that is true. I agree to a point that the rotation was very well utilized to create interesting scenarios for the player to enjoy. The mechanic itself is used too often. I enjoyed the game more by actually solving the puzzle. This mechanic was also melded together where exploring IS the puzzle so one can move on.
I feel they have done pretty much everything surrounding the rotation mechanic.

The game was created with lots of love, and it shows all throughout.

119099798.review:
An absolute gem of a puzzle-platforming game that first appears to be a simple, but, if you're up to it, has many layers of depth in its puzzles that can be frustrating at times, but always offer new and unique challenges to overcome. 

To preface the review focused on gameplay, it's worth noting just how good this game looks and sounds. Disasterpiece is an absolutely amazing musician that 200% deserves more respect. The pixel art is fantastic, and the semi-3D feature of the environment as you rotate makes everything look great.

Fez is a game all about perspective; not only from each "face" of the cube-world, but in its puzzle design. It's great for people not super interested in the meta puzzles, which require notes and creativity to solve, because it can be as simple as just rotating the world to get the golden cubes/cube bits in the right way and jumping. But for those inclined to look a bit deeper, there's a whole world to understand and get to grips with that asks [i]you[/i] to figure it out. 

The key element to exploration and beating the game is the map— at first it can seem very confusing, but with enough time, it gives you more than enough information (including which rooms [b]have secrets[/b]) that you're well equipped to explore everything the game has to offer. There are also "hidden" doors that link to random rooms, which are probably the poorest element of traversal, but with the many hubs and teleports between, I didn't have too many issues getting where I wanted to go.

The game ends when you collect 32 cubes— or at least that's what it wants you to think. There's an abundance of anti-cubes (32 of those) and red-cubes (3 of those) that provide further incentive to completing the game, with some being quite simple, and some of the others, being mainly red-cubes, having no explainable solution other than the community having brute forced it. 

I definitely recommend this game to just about anyone, and if you're struggling with some of the deeper puzzles, I'd recommend Absolute Steve's guide which attempts to give players hints without fully spoiling things.

118461645.review:
FASCINANTE es la palabra que mejor se adecua para describir a FEZ.
Es un videojuego que lo juegues cuando lo juegues siempre va a tener algo que te va a dejar inmerso en su mundo, un videojuego que plantea mecanicas tan adictivas como originales y las sabe exprimir de forma tan magistral que rara vez la sentiras repetitiva.
FEZ nos presenta un mundo habitado por unas personitas extrañas que viven pacificamente en poblados y en un mundo en segunda dimension (2D), de repente nuestro protagonista Gomez recibe la capacidad de poder percibir el mundo que lo rodea en tres dimensiones (3D) lo que nos introduce a la principal mecanica del videojuego que es jugar con nuestra perspectiva, nuestra forma de ver al mundo y las posibilidades que ese poder nos permite, ya sea encontrar pasadizos ocultos, objetos ocultos, mover objetos a la par de nuestra perspectiva y un larguisimo etc.

FEZ cuenta con una de las mejores banda sonoras retro que he oido en un videojuego indie, sin nada que envidiarle a juegos como Isaac o Braid, con tonadas ambientales y sonidos relajantes que te dejaran inmerso en el curioso mundo que te rodea y acompañandote para que resolver los Puzzles del lugar donde te encuentras sea una experiencia relajante y muy agradable jugablemente, ese es el apartado que me gustaria destacar de FEZ; Su constante intencion de ser amigable con el jugador y que este no se aburra ni se sienta agobiado con los variados puzzles que hay a lo largo de todas las zonas que exploramos, ya sea acompañandote con una tonada relajante y ambiental con sonidos de pajaros cantando y la brisa soplando, o presentandote una zona sin musica pero con sonidos ambientales como el sonido de una cascada, el cesped moviendose, los pajaros cantando y el sonido del viento.

FEZ es un videojuego y tambien una experiencia, que te invitara que te la pases de chill sin preocuparte por hacer diez mil movimientos o tener que esquivar veinte ataques por segundo.
Totalmente recomendado para los amantes de los juegos de Puzzles y de los videojuegos indies en general, pues es una cita obligada a todo fan del genero y sera un videojuego recordado en su historia.

(Lastima lo de su creador.)

118274023.review:
FEZ is, flawed yet beautiful to me.

This game has eluded me for years, I've wanted to play this since I played its demo on my old now broken PS3 in this games prime in the spotlight, and I haven't tried it until now.

This game is beautiful to me, yet flawed at the same time.

I love its maze-like open area design, it feels open where you can explore in a huge branching world where you can collect tons of collectibles while throwing cool gimmicks and mechanics and don't overstay their welcome. Every area has its own mechanic, which I respect immensely.

However, while on the subject of collectibles, that to me is where this game falls a bit.

This game will make you backtrack to places where you dont even know you have to go to, unless you remember every aspect of each area and know exactly what you're doing. Its a very unwelcoming aspect of the game that is impractical to new people coming into the game on their first blind play-through, so unless you want to take the challenge of doing this, Do not play this game, or alternatively look up a walk-through on how to collect them.

As this is said, I still think this doesn't ruin the game at all, it is still a masterpiece and is a staple of indie gaming history from its time. But be warned, If you want to fully complete this game, it will be tough and very time consuming and challenging, but even still, is a masterpiece, and is very charming.

118107708.review: I've played a lot of good puzzle games, I think. While I didn't spend nearly as long with FEZ as I might have with some of the others, (especially Picross dear god am I a Picross nerd) in that I spent a solid 12 hours 100%ing (well. in steam achievements terms.) the game and doing basically all I wanted to, I still feel like this game, as a puzzle, has done something no other puzzle game has, for me. And that is provide me with a situation where i'm like "holy shit these symbols have meaning.. I NEED TO TAKE NOTES ON THIS". And I mean that entirely genuinely positively. It was super rewarding to solve puzzles by putting together details that I've actually encountered in the world, develop hypotheses, get proven wrong, learn how it actually works, and figure things out on my own, and solve things. That's super rewarding to me. It's not perfect by any means, some things definitely stumped me and I couldn't figure out how to do important things and then I looked up how to do it and I'm like "well i'll be damned. if i paid attention to that detail I might have figured that out. I just didn't really know to pay attention to that specifically." to varying degrees of being miffed about just how cryptic the detail was. Some things I just never thought to try. Anyway, that's a sometimes thing for me. The puzzles I did solve on my own did feel very rewarding to figure out, and I can still appreciate the thought process behind some of the things I didn't figure out. All of this so far is to say nothing of the other various very nice things about this game, like how it looks with the 2d - 3d voxel / pixel mix and all, and the wonderful soundtrack by Disasterpeace. It's a very peaceful game. Very cute. Very detailed, there's clearly a lot of effort put in to the world and the things in it, and I love that. Even if you don't crack the codes for everything and figure out the significance of things, you can still clearly tell, abstract and stylized though this world may be, there are things that exist for a purpose, monuments to things that you don't quite fully grasp the significance of immediately, places where people once were but no longer are. Anyway, all that comes together to make a game that I enjoyed my time with. Solid indie title.

117129286.review:
(Spoilers)
A puzzle game where you play as a white man, going on an acid trip with his newly acquired, stylish, hat. On the way he discovers how to read the writings of a long lost civilization. After discovering 32 random cubes, he goes through a portal and the universe resets.

While going into the universe again, he gains magnificent sunglasses, to see things more clearly. In a 32-bit fashion. He starts looking for more cubes to satiate his hunger for completion. Overall he finds 64 cubes, goes through the portal again. He goes deeper into the rabbit hole. The universe resets.

There is still a small empty spot in his stomach, thinking he is still missing something. He enters the universe again. This time, he gets the ultimate weapon. The 3D-glasses. Now that he sees this 2D world in 3D, he tries to find some heart in it. He finds one part of a heart. Then a second. Then a third. Then he stumbles upon a door on a remote island. He goes through the door and finds the Temple of Love. The temple has a massive heart floating inside it. He inputs a code. And then... gains the heart of the developer.

117050044.review:
This game is an acquired taste. The last collectibles you'll nab are built around a language and puzzle system you kind of have to figure out yourself (about a third of all the collectibles if i had to guess), and some of the cubes are just completely absurd. 

If you can get down with a game with wack af puzzles, the fascinating mechanics, beautiful art direction, and the pure charm the game resonates will for sure be enough to pull you in (as it was for me, I've 100%'d this game three times outside of steam).

However, if you're not too inclined to crack this game open without a guide, the simple puzzle platforming probably won't be worth the money. And the guy who made the game is a dickhead.

I wouldn't recommend to anyone who I didn't already get the impression of liking this game, but this game means a lot to me. Thumbs up, but kind of a weak and shaky thumb.

116222959.review:
Fez a venido a mi por sorpresa y en parte por que ya era la hora de probarlo, desde que me entere que era "Uno de esos juegos indie, lo mantuve en mi mente, y cuando menos me di cuenta  ya estaba en descuento, por lo que decidí, sumergirme en el mundo de este juego, luego de casi 10 horas de juego, personalmente puedo decir que Fez es un Juegaso, tanto a nivel mecánico como a nivel personal considero que cada aspecto de este juego, incluso si esta echo para no verse tan fácilmente, tiene un nivel de atención al detalle  que hasta asusta, cuando salio este juego yo todavía ni siquiera pensaba en videojuegos como una gran parte de mi vida, pero aun así, me agrada que desde incluso tiempo atrás ya existían juegos y desarrolla dores que ponían un gran aporte a la industria, difuminando cada vez mas la delgada linea que los videojuegos tienen entre medio artístico y de entretenimiento.

Con lo anterior, por supuesto me refiero a en lo que Fez mas destaca, en este caso su premisa y su jugabilidad tan innovadora y creativa por igual, el simple echo de pensar en las dimensiones ya da para un tesis entera y aun mejor plasmar ese estilo en un videojuego del 2013 es una locura, acompañado por esa banda sonora tan relajante y tan satisfactoria, que incluso estoy pensando en comprarla para escucharla, los puzzels son ingeniosos y no han envejecido para nada, cada uno se mantiene fresco e interesante, por destacar algunos (SPOILER ALERD) puedo mencionar la fantástica  sección en donde si no mantienes el ridmo de la musica que te acompaña sera casi imposible continuar.

PERO, realmente este juego despertó no solo buenas sensaciones como su Bello final, ya que también me dejo pensando bastante muchas de las cosas incluidas en el juego, después de todo no todos los indies son joyas dignas de un museo y un legado, en este caso Fez falla en algunos aspectos...

Primero que nada, estoy consciente de el tipo de persona que es el creador de este juego y toda la lamentable polémica  que llevo a la cancelación de la secuela de Fez, cosa que ami en lo personal me parece de lo mas estúpido que e visto en mucho tiempo (y eso que veo noticias casi a diario xd), pero aun así, realmente tengo que destacar algunas cosas que no me gustaron de este juego:

Para empezar tenemos el control de nuestro personaje, el cual personalmente no es de mi agrado (cabe aclarar que esto es mas de mi gusto personal), en juegos como Hollow knight, pude tolerarlo y uno se puede acostumbrar, el mismo caso es en este juego, pero aun así abría agradecido un botón de para correr o aumentar la velocidad de nuestro personaje.

Otra cosa que de verdad va mas allá de mi gusto, son algunos de los puzzles, no me malentiendan, en su mayoría me agradaron e incluso hay un que otro que no voy a olvidar por su creatividad, incluso debo admitir que en algunos trataron de innovar, cosa que algunas veces salio bien (como el ejemplo antes mencionado) y otras rosa con la tortura, personalmente creo que: "ninguna mecánica, por tan buena que sea no debe ser llevada al limite para el jugador", un ejemplo que genuina mente odie, fue el puzzle de el reloj, (a no ser que visites una guía, la cual seguro que no te va a servir) para mi este fue la peor parte del juego, la cual consistió en prueba y error.

Otros ejemplos son los puzzles que tienen que ver con los anti cubos, y los artefactos, la mayoría de estos objetos no tiene una pista dentro del juego, lo cual por un lado esta bien, pero el tiempo que a pasado desde que se huso la investigación de este juego ya tiene mas de media década, por lo que muchas partes de juego van a ser muy confusas o directamente frustran tes.

EDIT: Algo que olvide mencionar es que hay bastantes bugs, los cuales tengo entendido no van a arreglar, si piensas en acabarte el juego en su totalidad, te recomiendo que seas paciente con estas cosas, que son muy pocas la verdad, pero lo que si que esta mal (no se si solo me paso a mi o es algo que el juego tiene de entrada), son los bugs visuales de el modo 3D, eso es algo que la verdad no me agrado para nada, mas que por los bugs que por el modo 3D.

Eso si, recalco que el juego es una maravilla técnica, la cual como mínimo tienes que probar una vez, en mi caso me engancho casi en su totalidad, incluso me llevo a acabarlo en su totalidad, y lo vuelvo a decir le juego me encanto y ese final a un mas.

90% RECOMENDADO
"Si te desesperas fácilmente o no estas acostumbrado a este tipo de juegos, personalmente recomiendo que no empieces por este titulo y busques uno mas "Sencillo" o que se acople a tus necesidades"

GRACIAS POR LEER :D

115920899.review:
FEZ is a fantastic puzzle game that also makes some of the best use out of pixel art out of any game. Often pixel art is used as a sort of indie staple, that gives it a certain feeling. For FEZ, the pixel art is a necessity, because it is how the game functions. Each level is 3D, but you can only see one side of it in 2D. By rotating the level, you get a new perspective that allows movement to somewhere else. 
Frankly, the puzzles are very well thought out. Brilliant use is made of this one core mechanic. The difficulty progression is great, and the later levels really are mind twisters. 
One key component is often searching for where to even go next. Because so many things are hidden on other sides of the same level, even finding the next door to go through can be difficult, as there are often many, branching paths. The exploration is never a bore though, because everly level is beautiful, with masterwork pixel art.
Anyone who likes puzzle games should pick this up. It is very relaxing, and easy to get lost exploring through the many branching environments.

115181835.review:
Fez was amazing. The platforming is pretty simple, but adds variation in different areas that keep it pretty fun. You hop and climb around collecting the necessary scattered cubes, but that's only part of the gameplay. The main event is figuring out the puzzles. And boy, are there a lot of them. Treasure maps to reveal hidden platforms, specific button sequences in certain areas, a secret (solvable) language of letters and numbers, and even QR codes are included. It was a blast to solve and work through. 

Some pointers for new players:
1. If you can't solve a puzzle in the moment, come back to it later. Do what you can first. 
2. The secret language IS solvable. There is a sentence in English that contains every letter of the alphabet at least once. Keep it in mind as you explore the world ;) 
3. Most puzzles are fair. You'll feel bad for looking them up. But a few near the end are ridiculously unfair, like just awful. (The eight cube passcode, the timing of the giant clock, and the 11 ways to unravel a cube). You may need to look those up. 

I really enjoyed the game! Good luck if you are going to play!
