114266718.review:
I've been wanting to play Fez for SO long. I was following the development, and I love lush pixel art, and all the colors, and Paul Robertson did some animation, and it's just . . . this game should be my Jam. But it's not.

Right off the bat, Fez envelopes you in its serene sound design and immaculate pixel placement. You control cute lil' Gomez, and he jumps and climbs around, and it's great. Then you get to twist your perspective around, and hey, that's the gimmick! That's cool! There are cool perspective puzzles, you get to, uh, see more perspectives, of the world, you know. And in order to progress, you have to see things from a different . . . perspective . . . .

Listen, I'm out of nice things to say. I loved the idea of exploring this world and collecting the shiny trinkets, so I set off on a grand journey. And I found a neat puzzle! You've got to set up these blocks so that they form different tetronimoes from each side. I pushed them around, got them in almost the right formation, but the controls wouldn't let me nudge one of the blocks in the right direction. So I tried again. Like seven more times. And the problem for me was: the physics of this world don't make any sense. The 2D interactions just *bug out* when in a 3D world. I got a block to float in mid-air with nothing below it, just by pushing the four blocks around. At that point I gave up, and decided to see if I had the idea wrong. And it turns out you can PICK UP BLOCKS? The game failed to teach me that I could pick things up. On top of that, the solution involves putting the blocks on separate shiny spots, *not* touching each other. That is *not* how the tetronimo do.

So anyway I solved that puzzle finally and tried to figure out where to go next, but the confusing in-game map did not make it easy to navigate (why are discovered warp doors not displayed?). Exiting and entering a room resulted in an unexplained change in the room, but whatever. The physics continued to be broken (rotating caused part of Gomez to be visible, but the instant he jumped, he was suddenly behind everything). Collecting a cube caused Gomez to levitate in the air right into a glitch that killed him, ruining my immersion further. I proceeded to walk through a doorway in just the right way to lock the game up and force a hard reset.

My experience deciphering the runes in the game: the alphabet is laughably easy but tedious, the number system is poorly communicated, and the tutorial for the input glyphs breaks the game's own pattern of reading right to left.

So anyway I beat the game. And there were some clever moments that I enjoyed. But most of my 10 hours was spent checking off boxes, craning my neck 90 degrees to the right, and looking up puzzle solutions when I wasn't sure what to do because there is literally a puzzle that the community had to brute-force in order to solve. Most everything in the game that doesn't involve the main gimmick is either finding a secret code that you input with your controls or clumsy platforming ideas taken from better games. There is no story to speak of aside from sparse, vague background details about the world.

I do Not recommend this game. The exploration runs counter to the incongruous world design. The precise puzzling runs counter to the sloppy character controls and physics. There are graphical glitches that impede my sense of immersion that are *separate* from the intentional glitches put into the game by design. The incessant saving icon impedes my sense of immersion. Decoding the hidden messages makes me feel like the kid from A Christmas Story when he gets his decoder ring. The keyboard controls suck except for the map screen, where a controller sucks. Why does Phil Fish have such a hard-on for Tetris? The ONLY Tetris in this game is all the tetronimoes everywhere, but they are literally Everywhere! Stop it Phil! You can make other shapes!

113844397.review:
[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/fez/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

FEZ is a game I got years ago, but was unable to play until now because it used a really specific graphics renderer that wasn’t supported by my crappy hardware. Now that I finally have a proper graphics card, I decided to try it out.

The premise of FEZ is that it’s a puzzle platformer where you move in 2D but can rotate the environment in 3D. This allows you to use perspective tricks like bridging platforms that are far apart at one angle but close together at another.

Unfortunately, this is not the actual gameplay of FEZ.

About halfway through the game, after you get all the easy collectibles that are solved through perspective puzzles, the game completely changes. All the remaining puzzles are absurdly tedious and obtuse, and mostly revolve around decoding ciphers that will tell you the solution outright. As in literally, the solutions are just sequences of button presses. After a few hours of flailing I gave up and just looked up the answers, most of which still had me boggling. (One puzzle is so bad the community had to [i]brute-force it[/i], and to this day they still don’t know what the intended logic was supposed to be.)

The cipher keys are generally very poorly integrated and not signposted at all — you are supposed to look at a fox jumping over a dog (in an area full of other wildlife that is otherwise irrelevant to gameplay) and make the leap that the stone tablet of moon runes next to them says “the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog”. You are also somehow supposed to realize that the numbering runes can represent the same number through multiple different systems, the only hint for which requires you to assume a series of moon runes is an arithmetic equation and also to assume that the symbol at the end means “10”. (And also that the writing system is top-to-bottom, and and and…) The game asks you to take way too many leaps of logic without any indication of if you’re going in the wrong direction.

Oh, and to developers everywhere: A puzzle that requires you to sit in place and wait for something to happen is not a puzzle, it’s just a waste of time. Stop doing this.

Now, this isn’t to say that there’s something inherently wrong with cipher puzzles. (Well, provided they don’t force you to crane your head 90 degrees for some ungodly reason.) But if you say your game is a puzzle platformer and it’s actually a cipher game, that’s false advertising and makes me very annoyed with you.

Overall, this game reminded me a lot of The Witness — it had an interesting concept of learning through observation that it proceeded to get bored of after five minutes and then spend the rest of the playtime pretending to be far more clever than it actually is.

113270172.review:
[h1] RESEÑA TRAS COMPLETARLO AL 100% (SIN SPOILERS) [/h1]

[b] JUGABILIDAD [/b]
Si buscas un juego de plataformas, te va a parecer demasiado sencillo. Si lo que buscas es un desafío intelectual, entonces has encontrado el juego perfecto.
La cantidad de puzles que contiene este juego es enorme, y aunque todos se basan en una mecánica similar, la manera de resolverlos es completamente distinta para cada uno. Además, posee varios finales y para acceder al "mejor" tienes que jugar al NG+, que añade una mecánica inesperada e innovadora para resolver esos rompecabezas que diste por imposibles la primera vez. Eso sí, recomiendo jugarlo con mando porque si no puede costarte bastante, y una posible pega es que el fast travel está bastante restringido, con lo cual tienes que acordarte de qué puerta lleva a qué sitio y mirar el mapa constantemente, hubiera preferido que pudieses teletransportarte a cualquier lugar desde cualquier otro pulsando en el mapa, por ejemplo.
Ah, y ten papel y lápiz a mano...

[b] DURACIÓN [/b]
El juego te llevará unas 10 horas si decides completarlo al 100% y no te atascas demasiado en los rompecabezas, aunque por lo que tengo entendido hay uno de ellos que fue resuelto por la comunidad usando fuerza bruta (tranquilo, no es necesario para los finales) y que todavía no se ha conseguido explicar del todo. No es un juego muy largo, pero por 10 euros está bastante bien y pasas un fin de semana entretenido.

[b] ATMÓSFERA [/b]
El juego es precioso visualmente. La estética 8-bit le pega muchísimo, cada área tiene detalles que la hacen diferenciarse del resto, la perspectiva es única (recuerda mucho al cuento Planilandia) y el personaje principal, a pesar de no hablar, se hace entrañable. La única pega que podría ponerle sería que la banda sonora se hace ligeramente repetitiva, y algunas escenas pueden marear o tal vez provocar episodios de epilepsia a algunas personas, cosa que otros juegos advierten y que no he visto en este. El lore que proporcionan los coleccionables, si eres capaz de descifrar el lenguaje del juego, es sorprendentemente profundo y filosófico, lo cual añade incluso más inmersión si cabe.

[b] CONCLUSIÓN [/b]

Ta weno COMPRALO

The translations can get tedious, and the puzzles that involve moving cubes (to spell words or make shapes) can be extremely frustrating, and there's a good chance you'll be reaching out to the internet for clues to help you complete the game

- BUT -

It's totally worth the ride. Shame the dev went overboard and cancelled the sequel.

105842355.review:
[b]TLDR[/b] In terms of bridge construction seems limited, but the Portal elements make for interesting challenges. [14/20⭐, 16h🏅, 3/5💡]

[b]Context[/b] Bridge Constructor: Portal is a bridge construction game in the Portal “universe”. I must say that I’m not a fan of bridge games, so to be honest I tried this one out just for the Portal concept. As far as physics-based puzzle games go, I’ve always felt that bridge construction ones depend too much on trial and error, and I end up brute forcing solutions (granted, probably due to my own ineptitude).

[b]Writing[/b] The most relevant thing about the Portal context is that you get to see GLaDOS again and the characteristic Portal sarcastic tone. Unfortunately, this is mainly explored in the first stages of the game, and by midgame interactions and any kind of narrative are mostly gone. But it if nothing else, it was enough to make me want to play Portal again, so there’s that.

[b]Aesthetics[/b] The design is inspired by the Portal setting.

[b]Gameplay[/b] In terms of bridge construction, Bridge Constructor: Portal seems to be rather limited (only 2 materials throughout the game). Most Portal elements are present, including repulsion and propulsion gel, buttons, laser fields, cubes and aerial plates, which make for some interesting puzzles. Oh, there are also portals, which I felt were the least interesting aspect. Failing a level has no consequences, and you can just reset. Level progress is saved and you can save multiple solutions.

[b]Value[/b] It took me 16h to get all the achievements, which is something. You can revisit previous levels from the menu. There are multiple endings available, depending on how far you progress in the game. Achievements are mostly related to "perfecting" levels, and triggering some events. There's also support for user-designed levels. Besides those additional levels, replay value depends on how obsessed you are with optimizing solutions.

101755368.review:
Fez stands out among puzzle games. It is a game that clearly has a lot of care put into it by the many who worked on it.


[b]Visual design[/b]
The art of the game is outstanding. It takes a theme and sticks to it excellently.
Each area has a very distinct feeling and you can identify its purpose in the overall world immediately - The peaceful airs of the observatory that reaches for the ever present constellations; The heavy industrial smog over the factories stuck in automated purgatory; The ??? of the r̷̠̣͂e̵̎̒͜d̷̞̘̒ ̷̢͖̆̕á̶̲̦͒b̵̪̖͗y̸̪̎́s̴͍͙̊̏s̸̳͒.

There is an absurd level of attention to details in each area; Animals unique to their area (Along with their own inventive visuals), landmarks, textures and sprites. No matter where you go, you will see something new. There is almost nothing I could suggest to improve upon the art.

Almost. I will say that the map screen is lackluster - It's very helpful and useful, but a needlessly difficult to understand and use. It'll lock onto things you don't want it to, the orthographic view, while in theme, leads to a lot of confusion. I think this stems from the difficulty of making a 3D map for such a unique style.


[b]Puzzles[/b]
The first thing that sets Fez apart from other puzzle games is its grand open world. As much as you're seeking out puzzles to solve, you're also always learning about the world surrounding them. The open world doesn't feel like a convenient package, it feels fully integrated into the puzzles.
Many puzzles can only be solved in the context of this world. The game features at least 3 unique "languages" for you to understand (Which, I must say, I can read fluently now). Breaking any one of them feels like a real accomplishment, and is integral to understanding some puzzles and the world at large. Some puzzles require you to have paid attention elsewhere, paintings and shapes. Many require strong reasoning.

Many have proclaimed the game is hard, with limited direction, but I object to this. First, there are very few puzzles that are required to beat the game. Without saying too much, you need to solve about half of the puzzles to beat it. If you get stuck on one puzzle, you can move on to a different one - If you decide to take on the harder puzzles, it will be because you want to.
Second, the difficulty of the puzzles comes not from some mechanical complexity, nor massive leaps in logic. The difficulty comes from the game trusting you enough to figure things out on your own, to pay attention to the world around you and take note of anything that might be important. You won't receive hints if you're stuck, you won't be told anything, you're trusted to take notes, pictures, make connections. There's no (required*) puzzle I felt had some unfair leap in logic, and it made solving all of them an experience to remember.

The difficult puzzles felt the perfect temperature for me, relating to existing concepts enough to be identifiable, but unique enough to provide something to think about. There are many smaller puzzles that act as reinforcement for ideas, and as nice rewards to collect as you explore the expansive world.


[b]Platforming[/b]
Everything I've said so far has been quite positive, but I must buck the trend here. Fez is not a challenging platformer - Not because it's uninspired, but because it's under explored. There's a lot of potential depth to the platforming: You have momentum and it carries, there's many types of platforms, and the game's core feature of changing perspectives has an absurd potential for exploration. But it doesn't utilize it very well.

I wasn't bored with the platforming in Fez (often). The platforming that is there is pleasing, there's a nice rhythm to some sections, you can find techniques to get around faster, and it complements the feeling of exploration the rest of the game cultivates.

However, there's not really a strong feeling of flow. Sections I [i]think[/i] were intended to be hard had me standing around waiting for the game to catch up. Many areas introduce interesting platforming challenges - That they use a couple of times and never again. It feels like a constant tutorial in terms of platforming, I always felt like I was waiting for it to really start. It does make backtracking a bit boring.

Worse yet, the 3D aspect of platforming is frankly poorly explained. Your z position (that is, towards the camera) is regularly shifted, and you have no way of knowing where you are on it - That is, until you change perspective, and find out it's put you at the total opposite end of where you wanted to be. The platforming is so simple however that this doesn't tend to be a problem, just an annoyance. There was one puzzle that required moving around a bunch of blocks that became a real nightmare because of this ever shifting Z position.

It didn't dampen my experience overall - It's still [i]good,[/i] but in relation to everything else that shines like a brilliantly polished diamond, it does feel a bit neglected.

101405017.review:
the gimmick of fez is done very well, allowing for very creative puzzles that are sometimes very difficult to figure out, however when i am able to figure out a puzzle, its normally done very well. along with this there isnt as much platforming as there is puzzles, so dying isnt really an issue, but when you do die, the animation is quick and lets you play immediately, and it respawns you right to your last safe platform to stand on. 

theres a lot of collectables in this game with there being anticubes, which are the hardest puzzles to figure out, the cube bits, which require 8 to make a full cube, which is used to beat the game. the cube bits are scattered everywhere and are placed in spots that arent the easiest but also not the hardest things. and theres enough collectables that fez can be replayed for a while, being 64 full cubes and anticubes, but you only need 32 to beat the game.

some of the anticubes are extremely hard to figure out, with basically requiring you to learn a whole ass language to complete, but these arent mandatory to do as theres so much more to do that you can still beat the game while skipping them. but most of the time i just googled the answers to the anticubes. but when you figure out a puzzle for an anticube, that feeling is always satisfying.

the movement is nice to control and can be mastered after a couple hours of playing.

however this game should have an epilepsy warning as a couple of the rooms in this game can and probably did cause seizures, which is a huge downside.

and also its really easy to get lost because of how much stuff there is to do, along with not being a great sense of direction.

but overall, its a fun game, and even though when this game was being developed there was some controversy and the creator of this game sucks, i can pass on that and give this game a 7/10. i would recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzles and isnt epileptic.

100509215.review:
FEZ is the number one Fez hat simulator of America, like a sub-game of Team Fortress 2. Seriously, why does he wear a fez? I dunno, but it's a strong personality. 

This game is awesome.

It's 2D world but in reality it's voxel-like 3D orthographic enviornment forced onto one of the four 2D side-view planes that you can rotate freely, the genius coming through the fact that it applies 2D physics rules to that afterwards, where you can navigate platforms like they don't have depth differences. It feels more of pleasant to navigate the levels using it than chore, combined with just a good feeling platforming physics, great graphics, great music.

But it's not a platforming-action game, it's exploration-puzzle game. Platforming is mostly pleasant, there are no enemies. Or much of friends outside of your village, leaving you feeling alone to experience new areas with music that get you feeling deep. There are 32 normal cubes hidden and 32 anti-cubes that are much harder to get. You only need to get 32 cubes to get a normal ending and extra ending won't net you amazing new lore either, it's ok to finish with 32 cubes. Go as far as you can. There are no abilities to unlock aside from one you get in New Game +, albeit you keep progress when you go NG+. So you can get your first normal ending anytime you want, go NG+ and continue getting remaining cubes for another ending orrrr for self-pleasure, like I did.

Because puzzles are really enjoyable there. There is some decypher ones that I didn't bother, at least word translation and numbers, managed to figure out the fancy command type. Was not a fan of QR Codes, ended up looking up guides as website didn't want to accept Steam's F12 jpeg screenshots. No, I am not using those QR code scanners on my phone, their permissions are mighty sus. But otherwise, very fun, especially how puzzles don't require you to find ability in another side of a map, usually, albeit there is one switch somewhere. But still, the desire to explore the mysteries, to tease my brain optionally and observe around for clues, it was really strong. I do wish game had in-game way to store some clues, but you won't need more than a single page in notebook.

Devs did want you to go and challenge yourself with puzzles and exploration as the very last part of normal cube is hidden along with anti-cube, haaa.

Lovely, highly recommended, Myst can suck it, it replaces it, fite me.

Oh yea, and there was Phil Fish. I call it "learning how Internet fame and Internet community works in mainstream in 2010 era". Which we didn't know, but, imagine this, gamers(tm) back then seriously thought that having strong shit opinion (like all ours) deserves witch hunting. Companies like Nintendo abusing human passion by CnDing fangames in our perversed copyright law, going far beyond the minimum requirement? Naaaah, it's fine, it's by law thus it's morally OK. Good thing I think that people are learning in 2020s.

I think Fez is one my favourite games of all time. I just love the little details, especially in pixel art games and Fez is loaded with them, not to mention **spoilers** hidden secret unlocks scattered throughout the worlds.

I still am disappointed and saddened that both creators had a falling out and that the most high profile one had such a negative experience with the reaction to his persona as portrayed in Indie Game the Movie that he quit the industry. 

I'm not here as an apologist, just lamenting the fact that more games from the same duo will never see the light of day.

Anyway, Fez is still very playable and is a must play for any fans of pixel art, platformers and just indie games in general. It's such a sublime experience and I think you'll love it, too.

After 100%ing FEZ within a day of beginning my playthrough I have to say it is one of the best platformers I have ever played. What makes it so good is that it's incredibly relaxing to play.

This comes from multiple areas such as the soundtrack, for one the soundtrack is well made and really adds to the game and when this is put alongside the art style it just puts you in a trance. The gameplay and how the 3D mechanic is utilised is really smooth as well despite it not reaching its full potential in my opinion as there aren't a lot of times where rapid flipping of the environment is required. The way the areas can basically be explored in whichever order you choose for the most part also adds to the game and the carefree nature of it.

My only real issue I take with the game is that some of the puzzles are ridiculously obscure and one took the internet bruteforcing it to solve. It is irritating to have to go and look for a guide mid play session because some puzzles were made basically impossible without people on the internet bruteforcing or datamining the game for the solution. 97664448.review:
For me Fez was a game that I really had to play through to the end to fully appreciate. And now that I fully appreciate it, was it worth playing through? No, not really.

Mechanically I don't think that the central gimmick of being about to rotate the level ninety degrees did all that much more that obscure or reveal the next platform to jump to. It didn't really add much to the difficulty of traversing the individual levels, but I found that it did make navigating the larger open world of the game more of a chore and got in the way of enjoying the game on a larger scale.

Also, the game feels like two different games taped together? The first half is a pretty straight forward platformer, and the second half is all about understanding ciphers and inputting codes? I'm not sure that it wouldn't have been better to just concentrate on one of these rather than switch track mid game. 

(On the topic of codes: I know that QR codes are neat and all, but having me pause the game three different times to look up a QR code is not what I call fun gameplay. Maybe QR codes were a lot more exciting back in 2012.)

All that said, probably the most unforgiving thing for me was how nauseating the game was. I was mostly okay with the levels rotating around, though that was bad enough, but then the game added more lights and motion on top of that. There's one level where a large part of the screen is literally obscured by a vignette of chaotic flashing tiles; and there were parts of a cutscene where I blocked out part of the screen because it was too much. 

I'm not generally even someone who suffers in that regard, so I can't imagine what it would have been like for people who do. I couldn't find anything in the settings to turn off those effects. I know it's just my imagination but it almost felt like the developer knew that the game was nausea provoking and decided to lean into it.

There is a decent game in Fez, but the journey to enjoy it was a pretty ambivalent one.

96670988.review:
If you're looking to have a fun challenge in a platformer, you've stumbled upon the wrong game. 

Right off the bat the gameplay feels poorly designed. Try getting a couple bits in any given level and you'll end up finding a door, which will lead you to grab another couple bits and even more doors. You'll end up losing yourself if you don't use your map, which by the way, is pretty awful to nagivate in. The game starts strong, but after a while... nothing happens. You quite literally only have to all the cubes, and there's no more to it. It's never addressed how the flat 2d people can have their rooms decorated in all dimensions when they themselves can't grasp the concept of "changing perspective". The game is completely devoid of proper story writing.

Then actual platforming is way too easy to clear, to the point where you'll seem like a speedrunner even if you're just casually going around. Once you clear a few levels, the perspective shifting mechanic becomes second nature and it loses its novelty. However, rather than exploring more ways to spice up the main game mechanic, the devs put most work into the puzzles.

And most puzzles, frankly speaking, are complete trash. It's like they didn't go through game design 101, putting absurd conditions to unlock the cubes. The most prominent type of puzzles relies on learning to input a sequence of commands by learning the symbols of the game, but it's not until late game when you're given a cryptic hint as to how to solve them. Then there's the bad puzzles that are impossible to solve without looking it up, like writing down a sequence in binary, turning it into hexadecimal and then to ascii. Pure madness.

Lastly there's the bugs. The game is full of minor bugs that show up doing basic things that shouldn't have made it past some playtesting. I'm baffled this game got GOTY back when it was released. I can see how all these bullshit puzzles that came up might have made people be in awe due to how "innovative" they were, but that's all there is to it. Out of spite I decided to fully clear this awful game, so I won't have a reason to play it ever again.

95446821.review:
It took a bit of time to get into Fez, but once that time came, it really hooked me in. with new ideas, systems, and thrown at me that I never expected. The main attraction here is the perspective-shifting 3D mechanic that most people already know from the trailers and descriptions, but these small pieces of the game don't reveal another core component of Fez: the secret-finding, collect-a-thon, and even code-breaking natures of the game. This unfortunately does mean the main mechanic of the game takes a backseat for the latter half of the game, and that the drawbacks of most secret-finding and collect-a-thon games are present, such as most newcomers practically needing a walkthrough or guide if they want to collect everything and some tedious backtracking if one misses a collectible in an area. 

For me, however, these extra things overall weren't a hindrance, but a supplement to the core 3D-shifting mechanic of the game and helped prevent Fez from wearing out its welcome. Add onto the charming, pixelated aesthetic, the calming soundtrack, and the quirky and beautiful art style and Fez proves to be an outstanding indie title that is incredibly recommended, with the caveat that one is willing to be thrown a curveball occasionally.

95051512.review:
[h1]FEZ – El Puzzle cambia según la perspectiva que se le mire.[/h1]

FEZ fue un videojuego bastante importante, ya que proviene de la década anterior en la que la industria Indie estaba comenzando tomar cada vez más fuerza con títulos como Don’t Starve, Geometry Dash o incluso Super Meat Boy. Presentando elementos únicos y un pixel-art sumamente enriquecedor y agradable a la vista con cientos de secretos y acertijos para resolver en un vasto mundo por explorar, todo esto acompañado de una música que complementa cada escenario y progreso de la aventura.

FEZ se caracteriza principalmente por sus mecánicas las cuales fueron y siguen siendo sumamente innovadoras a día de hoy. Ciertamente es difícil pensar en otro título que haya hecho una mecánica remotamente similar a la que posee este título, puesto que el principal distinto es poder cambiar la perspectiva del mundo en 4 diferentes ángulos y así, poder avanzar a través de los distintos niveles y rompecabezas que el mismo escenario nos plantea, algo que vuelve a FEZ sumamente único en su tipo, sin mencionar que los escenarios por los que avanzamos aportan pequeñas variantes, obtenemos nuevos objetos y novedades a la mecánica principal de rotar el mundo, lo que hace el juego bastante diverso de múltiples situaciones, logrando así que la monotonía no sea uno de sus problemas o desventajas, puesto que siempre habrá algo nuevo que ver, explorar, recolectar y resolver, por más mínimo que parezca en un inicio.

FEZ posee un apartado visual y sonoro muy ingenioso, armónico y complementario, no es solo por el hecho de que su pixelart junto a su paleta de colores sean muy bonitos a la vista o lo agradables, calmadas y motivantes que sean sus melodías; sino también porque cada zona es totalmente única acorde a lo que el juego quiere transmitir, y estos fungen en muchas ocasiones como guía y pistas hacía otros posibles secretos y misterios que por lo general suelen pasar desapercibidos. Rayos, el juego llega a poseer rompecabezas tan bien elaborados e ingeniosos que tiene hasta su propio lenguaje llamado “Alfabeto FEZ”, y no es sino por la mera observación del entorno y la perspicacia del jugador que logrará darse cuenta y desencriptar los mismos para avanzar a otros lugares aún más incognitos. Por suerte este tipo de retos FEZ se ofrece para dejarlos como algo ‘opcional’, algo para los jugadores más comprometidos y codiciosos con el 100% de los logros, por lo que aquellos que buscan una aventura más breve y personal no deberían tener muchos problemas o adversidades con llegar al final del juego.

Si bien todo lo que he mencionado de FEZ parece perfecto, tiene un pequeño problema que no hace que sea una obra maestra de su tipo, la cual es su historia o motivaciones del personaje. Quiero decir, en FEZ nos plantean una base, tanto la descripción de la página de Steam como los 10 primeros minutos de juego: [b]“Eres un personaje con cabeza rectangular llamado Gomez, el cual obtiene la habilidad de navegar y explorar de diferentes ángulos un mundo 2D gracias a un gorro Fez que obtienes al inicio del juego, y que tienes que salvar el universo por obras del destino”.[/b] Por lo cual aquí surgen varios problemas:
Si bien, al inicio del juego nos plantean las motivaciones tanto para nuestro protagonista como para nosotros el jugador, la verdad es que en ningún momento se profundiza y explora mejor este elemento, brindándonos mayor información acerca del peligro real que estamos aconteciendo o como el universo está en peligro en primer lugar, ya que su final simplemente nos muestra una serie de imágenes psicodélicas en bucle sin terminar de complementar la pequeña narrativa que tiene el título y haciendo sentir nuestras acciones como si nunca hubiesen tenido un peso o importancia real, más allá de entretener al jugador por un par de horas. Ya que incluso, no posee un desafío final que ponga a prueba todos nuestros conocimientos y habilidades adquiridos, como haría otros juegos como Super Meat Boy. Es uno de los errores que hace que FEZ no logre sacar su máximo potencial como obra independiente, ya que tiene una serie de elementos hermosamente cuidados en su mecánica, pero poco o nada en su historia y final del mismo.

[u]En conclusión:[/u] A pesar de lo anterior expuesto, no debe ser un motivo decisorio para no adquirir esta joya oculta e infravalorada del mundo de los videojuegos Indie, todo lo contrario, puesto a que como mencioné a lo largo de toda esta reseña, son más las características favorables y destacables que posee el título, brindando una experiencia desafiante a la par de entretenida, con grandes dosis de ingenio, novedad y creatividad [b]sea por donde sea la perspectiva que se le mire.[/b]

94926204.review:
The core mechanic and platforming are a lot of fun, and the music and environments are charming. Unfortunately, the core mechanic and platforming get abandoned around 2/3 of the way to the basic ending, and basically all of the rest of the game is a tedious collectathon where all of the "puzzles" are "translate various ciphers into a series of inputs that cause a cube to appear." One of those "puzzles" is just a QR code.

The game starts with Gomez being told that he has to save the world from a cosmic threat, this comes up once when an obstacle appears for the first time, and then is never brought up again. Neither the normal nor the special ending address this in the least, or address anything at all.

Fez could have been a 10/10 title if it kept its focus on the core mechanic and didn't forget about its minimal plot, but the majority of the content is valueless filler that retroactively poisoned my enjoyment of the good parts.

94438785.review: As of the time of writing this review, I've only reached the end of my first run - so I haven't grabbed every collectible yet. However, in what I did complete, I was having an absolute blast. While the puzzles themselves are relatively simple most of the time, I loved seeing how different parts of the map would connect to each other, and just how far they'd bend the 3D space they had. Twisting and turning the screen to take new perspectives is something I thoroughly enjoy, and it feels quite reminiscent of Captain Toad in that regard. The game is also fairly flexible in how you complete your first run - you don't need to grab x amount of Golden Cubes to open any given door, just x amount of cubes. So, if you were lucky enough to figure out how to snag an Anti-Cube, it actually counts towards your total. This means you don't have to scour every nook and cranny to find every yellow cube if you do manage to get a few Antis along the way, which promotes doing some of the more complex challenges. Overall, at least for a first run, I found this game super fun, and I would absolutely recommend it.

94133474.review:
FEZ is one of the most beautiful pixel-art games I've ever played. I generally recommend this game to my friends if I know they enjoy exploration and puzzle games, and if they like the art-style. If both of those things are true for you, I would certainly recommend you stop reading this review and give FEZ a try. I lost a good weekend (and then some) to this game, and I think it's well worth its $10 price tag. If you're still unsure, what follows is a slightly more in-depth look at the game, though I warn you there may be minor spoilers.

FEZ is absolutely gorgeous. You can see for yourself the level of detail that went into the art design by looking at Steam's slideshow of screenshots. What might not truly be captured in this brief preview, however, is the combination of level design, music, and background noise that give the world of FEZ its atmosphere -- somehow mysterious and warm at the same time. My entire adventure had me feeling like a stranger in a foreign land, yet at the same time as if I were rediscovering a home I'd long since forgotten. 

Most of the surface-level puzzles are simple and straightforward. You see bits of a cube, do some platforming to get to them, and continue to work your way towards either a whole cube or another area to explore. This is not [i]really[/i] the game of FEZ; this is just getting you familiar with the environment. There are a lot of little clues in FEZ -- seriously, even in the first little area there is a hint (perhaps more than one, I don't remember) to later puzzles. The real game comes from engaging with the world and getting immersed in it. 

There [i]are[/i] moments of frustration in FEZ. It was unclear to me at times whether the puzzle in front of me just needed more thought or if I was missing a crucial bit of knowledge that would let me figure it out. This led to me banging my head against a wall more than a few times. Unfortunately, while putting off a puzzle you can't solve is often a good solution, that requires backtracking. You will do a lot of backtracking in FEZ. There are a few teleports to major areas, however the puzzles you are likely to struggle with can be tucked away in areas far away from these teleports. You'll have to run back and forth every time you want another crack at a puzzle you set aside for a bit.

Furthermore, two of the later puzzles [b]do not have solutions you can find in-game[/b]. Yes, you read that right. One of them [spoiler]a literal black monolith[/spoiler] needed to be brute-forced in order to find the solution. Another required digging through the game's code. Correction -- people who worked on have [i]claimed[/i] that there [i]is[/i] an in-game solution to the first puzzle I mentioned, however how to arrive at the solution has been debated for [i]years[/i] with no conclusive answer. Some theories were built around the release date of the game's Xbox port -- seriously, the theories for how to arrive at the solution are absurdly convoluted. Personally I'm pretty happy with this puzzle, it feels like there are still mysteries waiting to be solved, and having to work on puzzles like this out-of-game, it almost makes FEZ come alive. 

Some things I didn't like about the game -- I found the companion to be pretty annoying. Sometimes when you turn the screen your character ends up behind the landscape and if you move while behind it you immediately fall. As mentioned before, I found the backtracking to often be frustrating, and a few of the puzzles had me smashing my head against a wall. Moreover, for puzzles like the one I mentioned earlier, there were times where the solution was difficult not because I was lacking information, [i]but because there is no known way to find the solution in-game[/i]. 

Overall, I enjoyed my time with FEZ. I hope you will too. If you can't figure out a puzzle within a reasonable amount of time, please move on temporarily -- it's possible you will learn something that will give you a new perspective. Pay close attention to the world, there are clues everywhere. Cheers, and good luck.

93866815.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 31.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

89547044.review:
Overall: A fun platforming-puzzle game that challenges the brain and feels like a huge achievement to complete. Very satisfying.

My trip with FEZ is a long one, but I can say confidently that I am glad I finished this game. I first got this game in 2013, and have only just now sat down to work on completing it. At the time, I didn't really understand the game very well, and it confused me a lot. Now, well, it still confuses me.

A lot of the game is just platforming and shifting your view to collect items, which are then used to open doors once you've gotten enough of them. Some of the items are used to understand the language used in the game, but honestly? It created frustration from me, so much so that I had to use a guide (shoutout to 'The Ultimate Guide to FEZ,' which was probably the only reason I stayed sane working towards 100%).

There are also QR codes in the game, which seemed cool, but... Yeah. Keep in mind that this game was made back in 2013, and at the very least, it makes sense for this game, being block based and all.

I would recommend this game for anyone who loves perspective-based gameplay, platformers, and brain games. Don't be ashamed to use a guide. (EDIT: Also beware of flashing lights and strobe effects, for the love of god play this in a well lit room)

89521734.review: To this day, FEZ takes the cake as my favorite 2D platformer of all time. Though it isn’t as quick or fluid as games like Celeste, its more laid-back, puzzle-heavy approach wins me over. Just exploring the world’s many branching paths while Disasterpeace’s incredible soundtrack washes over you is one of the finest gaming experiences there is. The puzzle rooms can get pretty difficult, but the open collect-a-thon structure means that none of them are required to finish the game. The best way to experience FEZ is by not knowing the primary game mechanic, but you probably just watched the trailer, so… unlucky, but still amazing.

89402816.review:
★★★★☆ Great

Thoroughly enjoyed this platform puzzler! Having a 2D side view of a 3D world and then being able to rotate it for 4 different views was a new game mechanic for me. Definitely enjoyed the puzzling challenge built-in by changing perspective to progress through the platforming levels. 

After initially completing the game, I attempted to solve many of the additional puzzles present throughout FEZ. One gripe is that some of the puzzles were quite gimmicky (for example using a QR code). Also, the artifacts would have been much cooler if they were more intuitive to interpret. I think I spent more than an hour trying to decipher the counting system looking at the counting cube before finally giving up and looking at a guide. Unfortunate that such a cool game is bogged down by unnecessary complexity.

89297835.review:
Couldn't get into this game. I played the "main story" and it was dull. The main mechanic is cool and it IS well implemented, but it still gets boring so fast. For a while I just kept going, playing a boring and easy platformer, waiting for the puzzles to get increasingly difficult. But the only things I found were mysterious objects, places I didn't know how to reach, and text I didn't know how to interpret, and which were seemingly irrelevant to the main goal of getting the cubes to finish the story. By the time I finished I was just playing to see what happened, maybe I would be able to read the weird signs everywhere, but I wasn't having any fun.

After "beating the game", just for curiosity I searched on the internet how to get to those seemingly unreachable places, and generally what were all those things I didn't get. And apparently I had missed more than half of the game. I couldn't believe the things I had to do and to think about in order to "start" that second half of the game. I like puzzle games, and games like baba is you and the witness both have "end games" which are accesible after a "hidden" puzzle, and which are noticeably harder than the main game, but by the time you end the main game in those games, you can have an idea of how to get to that second part, they are seamlessly integrated within the main game, and that second part is harder but still follows the same logic as the first. But in fez? Not at all. Not only the access of this second part is extremely difficult IMO, but it doesn't follow from the main game that is just about platforming and rotating the map to change the perspective. I had to look for it to understand what I had to do, and I didn't even do it because it wasn't something that seemed fun to do.

Having said that, if you like breaking your skull trying to unravel all the mysteries of a game with little information, and don't find travelling by platforming tedious, you may well enjoy this game a lot. But it definitely wasn't for me.

FEZ is, quite simply, a masterpiece. Get lost in puzzles, platforms, and pixel art.

89097503.review:
This was not the first time I played Fez, and the things that impressed me the first time I played it 10 years ago were the ones that impressed me this time too, so, in that respect, the game holds amazingly well, given that this is one of the first indies. 

There are many things to praise about the game, but the most important to me, which is the one that I hold most dear, is the exploration part. Getting lost in the world is amazing, try to find a way through the "pseudo-2d" map while slowly collecting cubes and fragments is a terrific experience. The fluidity of the platforming is also a wonder. I am not sure the developer  attended those 2 specifically, but from the interviews I watched about the game, there seemed to be other things that the devs paid attention too the most. In any case, exploring the place and the different biomes couldn't be done any better, kudos to the devs.

Similarly though, the things I was furstrated with 10 years ago were the same things that left me frustrated again. The thing that the devs seemed to have paid the most attention too, that is, the puzzles, and the concept that their solution has to be so obscure in order to be solved by the community so as to emulate the feelings that old games like the first 
Zelda's would give etc., is a wasted effort that ultimately spoils the experience. I know that many people are into these things, but it satisfies a very specific itch that really is not enjoyable to most. I dread the moments when I was wondering for more an hour why the room I was in is not "solved", and it turned out that the solution to it is more obscure than a solution for Cicada 3301.

In short, get the game and get lost in it, that's the best way to experience the game, and it does that part magnificently well, it is really a flawed masterpiece in that sense. Do not try to 100% the game without guides, it is not worth it, and it will slowly deprive you of your humanity.

88917116.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 33.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you Polytron Corporation.

87572961.review:
I find the music to be some of the best out there in terms of OSTs and is incredibly appropriate for the game. However, I didn't find the game to be particularly enjoyable. While it has a *great* concept, in execution I can't help but feel it doesn't quite snap together as it should at times. Jumping, and especially landings, are frustrating as it doesn't feel like I was ever very precise as well as the fall damage is extremely unforgiving. Its failure to impress me with its gameplay is a bit softened due to its fantastic, bright, and energetic color scheme and art design in general. It looks really great and I think it pulls it off well! 

Unfortunately, I do come looking for a good *game* and I don't feel like what I have is something I really enjoyed playing. The experience is game-centric, so it has a difficulty barrier which may keep some from being able to complete the game and experience all of the content the game provides. This means missing out on more of its great art and music. 

Because of all this, I can't recommend FEZ, BUT I do highly recommend not only its OST (original soundtrack) but also to explore other music from some of the featured artists. Really, really great stuff to be found in the music. As for the game - I'd say catch it on a "Let's play" or even a long play on somewhere like YouTube or Twitch. Just not worth the $10 IMHO.

update: Forgot to shout out Disasterpeace as the amazing artist behind the soundtrack. He's also done work on other games and movies. Check him out!

86547251.review:
[b]"FEZ'" is a unique platformer with inspiring gameplay mechanics, colorful pixelated aesthetics and an adorable main character. You will have a lot of fun solving some clever puzzles in a country that everything is related to visual illusions and space orientation. Some confusing moments and the absence of a storyline won't ruin the overall experience.


Manometer: 8/10[/b]


The good
- The concept of spatial illusions is clever. The world changes depending on how you rotate it.
- Cool aesthetics. Nice colorful pixelated graphics.
- Well designed world. There are many levels to explore each of them with its own color identify and design.
- Clever puzzles of all difficulties. There are some easy ones along with some pretty well hidden secrets.
- The gameplay is simple but effective and brings some small innovations.
- The main character is adorable. Actually every animal and NPC you meet looks great.
- Animations are smooth and so cute.
- Sound design consists mostly of electronical sounds and effects. It is simple but fits perfectly to the rest of the game's aesthetics.
- There are some points that it is hilarious. You will have fun.

The bad
- Sometimes you need to walk all the way back to get to the previous level. Especially when climbing down is necessary, it is painful to do it without dying.
- The controls on the map's menu are a little bit frustrating.
- I experienced some crashes on desktop.
- This green/black effect on the underground levels is annoying.
- The story is too abstract. It would be so much cooler if it had a basic plot. The ending is a little abrupt too.

83640300.review:
FEZ is probably one of the best puzzle games ive experienced playing, while having a few hiccups in the moments before completion. 

so many times while playing this an "A-HA!" moment comes up, and it feels EXTREMELY good, because you EARNED that cube, you knew EXACTLY what to do to get that anti-cube, and it's that little burst of serotonin that gets you motivated to fully complete more and more of this game. 

while these moments definitely aren't few and far between, some are definitely a bit more "Oh come on." worthy than others, and some of THOSE are just, really, really stupid. I would be stuck trying to find more cubes for a good couple of hours, just to randomly stumble upon something that gives me the key to a few more cubes. like yeah, it felt good to FINALLY have this little chunk of the game done, but how was I supposed to know that was going to appear? what was going to give me clues to that? It's not NOT subtle, but it definitely felt like banging my head against the wall until something happened. Dont even get me started on some puzzles akin to, the black monolith, or the security question. 

despite the "Oh come on." and worse puzzles mentioned before, this game felt great to progress through, especially with the satisfying all gold map you have once you 100% (or, 209.4%) the game being something to look forward to.

definitely play this, it's worth the "head-banging-on-wall-ing" that'll you will 100% experience while going through this journey. you ALSO shouldnt feel bad about looking up walkthroughs, phil fish didnt design everything with the intention of "oh they'll figure this out WITHOUT wanting to pulling their eyes out". 


(By the way, the soundtrack? Holy shit. Please listen to it on it's own, disasterpeace perfected something with this.)

83578979.review:
[i] Fez [/i] is a very difficult game to write a review for. Not that the game is bad, far from it, only that it is difficult to describe why the game is so good without going on a tangent describing minor things that I liked about the game. Sure, I could say that this game has fantastic environments, wonderful animation, and a beautiful soundtrack; but all of these things are discovered when playing the game. However, in the interest of time I believe that if you have any interest in this game you should [b] definitely [/b] play it. If you are skeptical about purchasing this game then you should read on.

[i] Fez [/i] has garnered quite the reputation as being the difficult puzzle game that was made by an overly sensitive developer who did not respond well to criticism. Whatever your opinions are of Phil Fish, I believe that this game should be viewed on its own merit without accounting for what was largely fake news and media hype over certain things Phil Fish has said. With that out of the way, I would like to discuss why this game is so clever and unique.

Much can be said about the puzzles in [i] Fez [/i]. Sure the game does have difficult puzzles but I don't think they solely define what makes this game special. Sure, the puzzles are fun to solve and very unique in their own right, but that isn't all there is to the game. The art style may not seem unique with how many retro-style, 16-bit games there are on the market nowadays, and you may be tempted to overlook the game because of that. [i] Fez [/i] was one of the early pioneers of this art style and I think credit should be given to the game for opening the market not only to other indie studios, but also for the massive influx of nostalgic 16-bit titles. The soundtrack of this game is by far one of the best I have ever heard. I don't want to spend too much time talking about it so I will just say it is excellent and leave it at that. The animation and stages of this game are so well done, but I digress.

It would probably be in my best interest to talk about what this game is: a puzzle platformer (with a heavy emphasis on the puzzle portion). All that needs to be said about the platforming in this game is that it is decent, there are some portions of the game that could induce nausea due to platforming and using the unique rotation mechanic that this game offers, but that would be too much to get into. As for the puzzles, the puzzles of this game are (for the most part) pretty good. Most puzzles can be solved using internal logic that is defined by the game but some require knowledge and intuition that I think most people lack. I am not saying that I have solved every puzzle in this game (and I don't think I will), but I am warning you that you may need to consult a walkthrough or a guide that provides hints to some of the puzzles. There are no shortage of resources online that provide hints to the solutions of the puzzles without outright spoiling them (and I have used my fair share of them throughout the game). I recommend that you try to avoid these guides and use them only when absolutely necessary as solving the puzzles in this game provides an intrinsic satisfaction the likes of which I have scarcely seen in other games. I don't think it is necessary to complete all the puzzles in this game to gain your money's worth and only think the puzzles after the credits of the game are for the most dedicated and ingenious of people (that which I am not).

To summarize, I think [i] Fez [/i] is one of the most wholly unique games that is offered and I think everyone should experience this game, and people who like a good, challenging puzzle will really enjoy what this game has to offer.

83126023.review: Fez is the quintessential indie game: lovingly hand-crafted by a select few, then polished incessantly until it is tightly knit together into a seamless whole. It's a puzzle platformer set in a beautiful, pixelated world with graphics that are evocative of the golden age of gaming. The 3D / 2D mechanic is also an innovative throw-back to the world when games weren't designed by committee and limited to only a few genres. This is a game where you can explore, think, and relax - a classic both in its own time and for the ages.

81921949.review:
I hate this game. The difficulty scale is all over the fucking place and the gimmick isn't even interesting. Most of the puzzles can be described as "turn the camera until you're looking in the correct direction" and there's very little skill involved beyond some light trial and error. This game also does the thing where the every single level is connected, but since each level can be connected to up to six (!) other levels, it's impossible to navigate. I got through about 90% of the game before realizing there was a map and once I started following it, it literally didn't help at all. The music is uninteresting, The story is--well, there is no story. The other characters that you can find on a few levels serve no purpose and have no relevant dialogue. The one thing this game has going for it is the pretty graphics. This game is really pleasant to look at, but that doesn't really count for shit because it's a pain to play. I haven't even gotten to the worst part yet. Remember at the beginning of this review when I said the difficulty was wack? Well, I only explained half the issue so far. While the normal puzzles that you need to solve to progress are easy, some of the secrets are absolutely impossible to figure out. If you play through the game normally, you will probably begin to suspect that there is more to the game than just solving basic perspective puzzles. In fact there is, and I'm going to explain why it's bullshit, but don't read it if you care about figuring it out for yourself, though I doubt you will!  

[spoiler]Throughout the game, there are runes etched in stones scattered across the levels. If you thought they were just decorative, YOU ARE WRONG. They come in two varieties, one of which encodes camera instructions, and one of which encodes hints in English. Now, I was able to figure out the simpler code after hours of head-scratching but I was absolutely stumped as to what the more complicated one could mean. I ended up googling it and it turns out that there is one otherwise innocuous room tucked away in a random location that has "The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog" scrawled on a blackboard in the background, and that's how you're supposed to figure it out. Now, I had been to this room several times but I didn't even SEE the blackboard because it BLENDS RIGHT INTO THE FUCKING BACKGROUND. Not only that, but there's no indication that this one wall out of ALL THE RANDOM WALLS IN THE GAME is useful to solving the puzzle. It's not like this is the only room that doesn't otherwise serve a purpose either! There are a bunch of empty rooms that do absolutely nothing but this one in particular happens to be the key to solving LIKE A QUARTER OF THE SECRETS IN THE GAME. Honestly, the one moment of enjoyment I had while playing the game was when I figured out the first code. I really felt like I had accomplished something. That feeling went away after I looked up the second one. It's not like solving these puzzles unlocks anything interesting either! It just lets you get whatever collectibles you hadn't gotten yet.[/spoiler]  

The nonsense doesn't end there, though. There's an optional puzzle in this game that has a solution so obscure that the only way people figured out how to solve it was by fucking BRUTE FORCING IT. Did I also mention there's a puzzle in one of the levels that requires you to wait actual DAYS in real time to complete, with practically no indication of how much time is left? And if you don't happen to catch it at the perfect moment then you have to wait all over again? Yeah, real engaging gameplay Phil. Ugh. This game somehow manages to be the least challenging and most insanely difficult game at the same time. It's a bloody miracle. So yeah, Fez is a fucking mess. If you don't believe me, try it for yourself. You'll experience the boredom, the loneliness, the frustration at not being able to solve the most cryptic shit ever, the feeling of emptiness inside your soul as you traverse dozens of indistinguishable maps looking for some secret that you missed, only to find [spoiler]some shitty runes etched into a rock that you don't know how to read[/spoiler]. "Oh well," you'll think to yourself. "I'll come back to this later when I've figured more things out." And you will come back, again and again, only to be just as clueless as the first time. Fuck this game, fuck Phil fish, and fuck all the cocksukkers who call it a masterpiece. 2/10.

77734439.review:
[h1] First Impressions [/h1] 
FEZ was talked about as an amazing game long before I got it, one where I'd have to unravel a complex puzzle in order to complete everything. Having to keep in mind how rotating the world 90 degrees changes everything's perspective and what you're capable of doing one screen to the next lent itself to a great-sounding game I wanted to try for myself. Upon doing so, I can't say I'm surprised by how many layers there are to the puzzle elements, though I really am at a loss for what I could possibly do beyond what I've already figured out by this point. 


[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
At its best, FEZ will perplex and baffle you for a while, but as you start understanding how the game functions and what you're expected to do, you'll begin solving puzzles and fall further down the rabbit hole. This elation is contrasted by the bewilderment and frustration from FEZ's most perplexing and mind-stumping puzzles. On many of the late-game puzzles and secrets, I admit to having no idea where to even begin, and I mean that almost literally. The map showing all the areas gives an indication of whether you've cleared it or not, but even within an area where I know I'm missing something, I can be completely lost as to where I should be looking so I can even try figuring out the puzzle. Some of this is made worse by the fact that although there aren't many moves or mechanics that open up late-game, there's a crucial one that could be hiding an important clue. Additionally, I may have noticed a hint or solution somewhere else in the game, but have no idea where it's supposed to be used.

Since FEZ has a unique style and approach to puzzles, with no prior work from the developer to understand his mindset, I don't think all of his intentions were conveyed clearly to us as players. I'm aware there are guides for all the puzzles in the game, but I don't know if anyone understands where all the solutions were in-game, what the clues were supposed to be that connects those dots. Making a hard puzzle isn't difficult, as all you have to do is tell someone to enter in the correct 6 digit password with the answer hidden 'somewhere,' which should be doable even without the clues because there are only so many possible solutions. Whether they can brute force it and get the solution isn't the issue, because a good puzzle has enough of a basis that a person can understand the problem, work through the clues, and provide the answer. At the very least, have a semblance of what's going on if someone else solves it and offers an explanation. With FEZ, finding the puzzle can be a challenge in itself, let alone figuring out what elements in the game are distractions and which are clues.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2257030603
[h1] Controls [/h1] 
The controls in FEZ center around platforming and rotation, and you can do so with either the keyboard or controller. I never had any problems with the controls responding properly. Moving left and right is done with the 'D-pad,' or 'L joystick' while climbing up and down is done with the same. You'll jump with the 'A' button, and rotating the perspective 90 degrees either direction is done with the 'R and L triggers/bumpers.' Rotation isn't instantaneous, but you can hold it down if you need to turn it more than once. 'Y' bring up your inventory and 'Select' brings up the map screen. 'Start' goes to the main menu. Much later in the game, you can bring up a first-person perspective by pushing in on the 'L joystick.'


[h1] Story [/h1] 
You control Gomez, a young lad who goes to speak with the town's elder, who winds up giving you a nice fez. This innocuous hat winds up opening a whole new dimension, and your task is to learn what's going on with the world and help establish balance. Doing so introduces you to sentient cubes, who want you to collect smaller cubes. Some are found pretty easily, while others require you to backtrack and use what you learn or find in one area in other parts of the game. What will happen when you do as the cubes wish? That's just another part of the mystery.  


[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
Although the deep levels of puzzles are the most impressive part about FEZ, I'd say the graphics are a close second. The environments are whimsical, colorful, and when you look closely, are drawn well. As you find new areas and sub-sections, these areas will develop a theme and aesthetic that creates a different tone for these locations. For instance, I find the place with the owl statues somewhat grim and eerie. Additionally, for the puzzles to work, every background had to be considered from the perspective of rotating the screen 90 degrees, and each setting fits into the next screen cleanly. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2257031132
[h1] Sound Design [/h1] 
Aside from certain events, such as rotating the screen, there aren't many sound effects in FEZ. This leaves plenty of quiet moments for the soundtrack to play out clearly. The music in FEZ is varied, to help fit the different settings you come across. Some have a laid back, calming aspect to them, while others have a slow build-up and almost sounds ominous. The soundtrack is certainly a positive element in FEZ. Going back to the sound effects briefly, when you do find a cube or solve a puzzle, it feels especially triumphant with the accompanying sounds that play. This is a nice emphasis that makes those moments stand out. 


[h1] Pros [/h1] 
🌟 This game's version of a map gives enough information that it can help you determine where you should be going next or what areas need to be looked over again. For instance, when you fully clear an area, it'll have a gold border. 
🌟 Finding a new area you overlooked before and solving puzzles that confused you earlier provides great "Eureka" moments that make solving puzzles so enjoyable. 
🌟 Although FEZ includes platforming, it's basically window-dressing for a gigantic puzzle. 


[h1] Cons [/h1] 
❌ Our minds are hard-wired to find patterns and meaning where none exists, and since part of playing FEZ involves searching everywhere for such clues or answers, it's hard to know what falls into that category or not. "Those blades of grass... they're spaced out in such a way that I could enter this in as an answer somewhere." 
❌ There's no way to take notes or place reminders in-game, and with how labyrinthine FEZ can be, it'd be quite useful. As would being able to teleport from area to area, instead of having to trudge from one place to the next. 


[h1] Tips [/h1]
🔍 If you want to solve puzzles on your own instead of resorting to a guide, you'll want to take clear, detailed notes. Taking pictures with a smart phone would be helpful too. 
🔍 Take an occasional break from FEZ, as sometimes stepping away for a short while will let your mind rest, with the puzzle being easier to work out afterwards. 


[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1] 
FEZ is an incredible puzzle game that shows how creative and interesting puzzle games can be, even for those who wouldn't consider themselves fans of the genre. I've seen many puzzle games that are nothing but the puzzle mechanic, and though it has its place, it reminds me of buying a book of Sudoku, word finds, or crosswords. Why play the video game equivalent, with so much potential for more, if nothing interesting is done with it? FEZ wouldn't have any significance if it were nothing but a series of block-turning puzzles, and I hope others will be inspired by what was done here. I recommend FEZ, as well as whatever guide you use to solve the areas where it becomes too cryptic.

76503754.review:
[i]Fez[/i] is a puzzle-platformer, where you move the main character in a 2D plane until you rotate the camera/world to get a different perspective. It’s an incredibly unique take on the genre, and unlike any other platformer I have ever played. There are a few shortcomings, but overall it’s a great game.

While collectathons have had their unique genre recently stained with grindy open world games, the seemingly endless quest for items in [i]Fez[/i] is actually amazing. You collect cubes which allow you to unlock some areas, where you find more cubes to unlock more areas etc. This is all supported by a neat little tongue-in-cheek story with some some fun and interesting moments. The environments are very nicely detailed and compliment the world Polytron has built. 

The biggest drawback is the secret language spoken by some of the NPC’s, and that inscribed on some statues in the levels. It’s not essential to complete the game, but it still sucks that there is a ton of dialogue that you don’t really get to easily read. Even once you are able to decode it (which I genuinely think is nearly impossible without a hint or guide), you still have to individually translate everything. Would have been so much better if one of the artifacts you pick up automatically translated everything after you input the solution. Keeps the puzzle solving aspect but makes the result more enjoyable. 

Regarding the level design, when I started playing [i]Fez[/i], I felt that stress often experienced during metroidvanias where you feel like you’re missing out want to go back. Except turn that feeling up to 100. I kept going through areas and thinking “oh man, I missed an exit two levels ago…what if I went the wrong way??” My number one advice to newcomers is to keep pushing through. Just don’t stop exploring. I forced myself to forget about other passages I missed, and it was the best decision I made. Exploring this endless rabbit hole of levels and worlds was addicting and exciting. 

The art style and music is also fantastic. The synthesizer-driven soundtrack by Disasterpiece is heavenly, sharp, dreamy and poignant. Every single track perfectly fits the level you are in. If I had one complaint about the art style, it’s that there are quite a few levels that are just kind of “there”, and are indistinguishable from other levels. But otherwise, the colours complement the blocky 16-bit feel, and there are so many unique environments.  

I wish the fast travelling was better implemented. It definitely gets better on your second playthrough, once you start to remember where some of the shortcut doors will take you, but I would have liked some kind of additional indicators on the map. Re-platforming some areas can be a slog because the controls aren’t super tight.

I suppose the most frustrating part of the game is the absolute reliance on a walkthrough for a some of the puzzles. There is a whole secret alphabet and numbering system which is incredible…but deciphering it on your own ranges from extremely difficult to nearly impossible. I almost made it through, I probably had to look up 10% of the games secrets, but some of them I wouldn’t have guessed in a hundred years. (And apparently, one of them was guessed at random by the community and there is no proper solution as to what it is.) I will admit, something like that is kind of cool, and very avant-garde. But as someone that just wants to be able to figure stuff out, it’s also annoying lol. 

In the end, I’d give this an 8.3/10. It’s such a great game, but short of being a near-perfect one because of some of those puzzles, back-tracking and the secret language. The last one may seem unfair to call it out, but if you hide a lot of the game behind something that is genuinely difficult to decipher, it’s not so fun. My playtime is a bit longer than others because I really tried to solve as much as I could on my own.
