76354081.review:
To me, the most important metric when I'm trying to decide if a puzzler is "good" or not is "does it force me to take notes?".  While Fez can be partially completed ("the bad ending" which was still pretty awesome and soul-stirring) without a notebook, you'll probably need one to clear it 100%, which speaks to the depth and creativity of the puzzles.

Fez is a unique puzzle-platformer, I want to call it 2.5D but that's not quite accurate.  While the game basically plays as a side-scroller, you can rotate the world 90 degrees along its Z-axis left or right, showing you a new perspective of your surroundings.  The mechanic is employed brilliantly, as puzzles sometimes have you gripping a mechanical wheel and rotating your view, for example, or rotating while jumping on platforms to make moving or rotating platforms correlate with each other differently.  There is a great variety of platform puzzles, perspective puzzles, stacking puzzles, linguistic/crypto puzzles, and a big interconnected series of settings to map out and search for clues and secrets in.  The core of the gameplay loop is exploring and inspecting environments for pieces of cubes, fully assembled cubes unlock doors that grant access to different areas of the game and secret passages that connect them together.

The gameplay never really gets stale or repetitive, and is consistently a joy to play.  You could sort of consider the game similar to a "metroidvania" with the exception that you never obtain any new abilities in the game - which is fine, that's not the focus.  You do however revisit parts of the interwoven stages of the game with a new perspective (hah) on the puzzles.

The visual design and animation is top-notch and distinctive, with a high-FPS retro pixel vibe that shifts through bright primary colors, eerie monochromes, and subdued muted palettes.  The music is equally well-designed to give each space its own mood and stands up as one of my favorite game soundtracks in this faux lo-fi style that recalls early video games while also making full use of the dynamic range of modern sound hardware, sounding lush and detailed while also recalling that purity of older game music.

This game is enjoyable for a wide range of ages.  I found it a very high quality gaming experience as an adult, and I've successfully gotten 5-6 year-olds through the game with some coaching.  Fez does not contain any violence at all, although there are a couple sections where you destroy crumbling landscape features with cartoonish bombs that you lift and throw as puzzle elements.  

I've never encountered another game that quite accomplishes what Fez did, it's one of the more unique gaming experiences I've had.  This is a solid full-price purchase if you enjoy puzzle-platformers at all, or if you enjoy metroidvania-style games and are interested in a more chill experience that is not rooted in combat.  Gamers who enjoy exploring and figuring things out for themselves without explicit instructions will enjoy many hours of "aha" moments playing Fez, and the Z-axis rotation mechanic quickly becomes natural enough that you'll find yourself using it just as readily as the jump button and thumbstick/D-pad.  Fez is also quite comfortably playable on a keyboard.

76341327.review:
I was feeling overwhelmingly nostalgic for this game recently after listening to its OST again, so I decided to write a short review.

Despite a lack of story, this game does an exceptional job at creating a mysterious, disjointed world full of intrigue. To me, the atmosphere and settings tell a story much like the way instrumental music does: it's archetypal, it transcends words. There's abandoned, crumbling industry hinting at civilizations long passed, as well as serene environments illustrating many different eras in which man-made architecture and the natural world collided, all of which now wholly devoid of sentient life again. We have no idea what happened, and the game doesn't make any effort to tell you. There's also the contrast between the small 2D village Gomez comes from, the abandoned "worlds" mentioned previously, and [spoiler] the city you eventually stumble upon with the people privy to knowledge of the 3D world [/spoiler]. Many people have claimed that the creator simply failed to write a cohesive narrative for one reason or another, but I'd like to think he kept things intentionally vague and indirect, unlike most games.

While on the topic, I don't have much to say about Phil Fish, the developer. Apparently he became very angry at the video game industry and at some point quit altogether. I know very little about other controversies he may have been involved in, but whatever the case, he as person does not impact my view on his game in the slightest.

The gameplay is very platforming and puzzle-oriented, both of which I'm very fond of. The game's core mechanics that allow you to explore a 3D world through the lens of a 2D being is certainly unique, and is a whole lot of fun. The punishment for death is next to nothing, which encourages trial and error as you attempt to navigate the strange world of FEZ.

I absolutely love great pixel art, and FEZ delivers in this department as well. The landscapes are bright and colorful when they need to be, but also dark and foreboding in other places. Most scenes are also strangely lonely.

As for the music, Disasterpeace is an incredible individual. He never fails to deliver music that elicits nostalgia and other raw emotions from me, and he absolutely perfectly captures the atmosphere of each setting in FEZ. I can think of few other musicians who similarly are able to auralize such sentimentality for the beautiful landscapes in FEZ. I also love how the music changes with the game's day/night cycle, as well as how the rhythm changes based on certain events or on its own irregular timer.

Finally, there's a lot of additional depth to this game as far as puzzles go, but you're not at all required to figure them out to complete the game. You may attempt to unlock the "good" ending if you wish, but these puzzles are so convoluted that the average person will need to look up a guide to complete them.

I played this game years ago, and I still get a little emotional every time I listen to this game's soundtrack. I suppose it's one of those things that you either get engrossed in, or you just get extremely bored. I was obviously the former, and I hope this game speaks to you the way it did to me!

Just finished my play-through of this over on my Youtube channel, so if anyone wants a sample of gameplay to help decide whether to buy, see here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nzWWKTBuXw&list=PL05Yc3_TEBpMXDLt1oVpe-oNYx97-Vz_M

Now, some thoughts. I definitely recommend this game if you're into platformers, especially 2D platformers. The colourful, pixellated retro graphical style is gorgeous to behold, and the gameplay is simple but fun. What I liked most of all was accessing new areas; the game world is divided into numerous places for you to find, with each of these places grouped together into areas with their own distinct colours and aesthetic.

There's plenty of collectibles to find, though be warned: if you're aiming for 100% completion, some of the puzzles are very challenging. There's an in-game language and numerical system you have to decode, as well as various puzzles featuring a code based on an old, classic retro game (I won't say which one; I'll leave that for you to figure out). Hell, to be honest I had to look online for some of the solutions! Not that I felt that was too much of a bad thing, personally.

The only thing I didn't like about this game was the clock room puzzle. I won't say too much about it here, but you may have to tweak your computer's clock in order to speed this one up and get some of the collectibles. I might not be a game designer, but if I was, let's just say that's the sort of puzzle I would not put in a game.

But other than that, my experience of Fez was very good on the whole. I definitely recommend it.

So I finally got to play the game a bit, but short story short: I didn't play past the first village where I only collected a few of the hidden "Very important, collect them or everything collapses" cubes. It probably was meant to be sarcastic/funny/unimportant since it's presented like this by Clippy from Zelda, but it didn't have to be that way... It only made me think there was actually nothing of interest in the game to show, so here's some filler story to set up a task, so you can get going and do the "interesting" task of collecting cubes by exploring this perspective-changing mechanic.

Based on what I've seen people discuss online, beyond the surface, there's a "delicious" part consisting out of obscured codes and secrets hunting, but for me that's a wrong direction to investing in when building up your game. Sure there are probably some nice puzzles in the game, but I'm only guessing...

Anyway, maybe I had wrong expectations regarding the nature of the challenges this game has to offer, maybe I mistook the adventure part for a chore and gave up too early, and maybe the intro/presentation and the pacing of the game is to blame for that.

This game is definitely targeting a narrow category of players, which I unfortunately am not a part of. I do enjoy puzzle games, don't get me wrong, just not this type.

Out of curiosity I've looked at hours played by people in my friends list. 8/12 played less than 2 hours, 6/12 played less than 1 hour... which shouldn't mean much, since I definitely don't enjoy what most people do, but maybe it does mean something, who knows?

73176207.review:
Overall, this game was quite a fun experience. It's been a while since I've known about it and I finally got to play it (even if it's seven years later).

The music and the retro look were nice, and the puzzles were also quite entertaining for some time, even though i got some of them by complete accident.
The sheer concept of a 2D world suddenly going too a 3D one is quite a good one, and it's really catching,and proven efficient for several good platforming puzzles.

However there are still some drawbacks that were sometimes a bit frustrating. 
For instance, the momentum with jumps felt quite awkward at times, especially with moving or crumbling platforms. Another thing that was a bit of a shame was the reutilisation of the same puzzle mechanics, sometimes a bit excessively (for instance : the pillars giving a code when entering in first person view (4 cubes), or the code giving trough stereo audio (4 as well)). The latter felt a bit repetitive, only in order to have the correct number of anticubes in the end without having to create other mechanics. 

Anyway, the way the puzzles were made (ie. finding clues for puzzles found at the beginning of the game at the end of the first playthrough) was quite interesting and added great replay value.

Definitely recommend for people who are not afraid to be met with several headscratchers.

72256079.review:
7.7.2020.									Game #140

[h1] A good game that managed to frustrate me more than I’d like to admit [/h1]

Fez is a good game, in fact, it’s great. It’s the kind of game that you can only really appreciate if you played many video games and can appreciate when video games stray from their usual path. I want to say that I really hate this game, but that’ only because I have a tendency to finish games like Fez 100% and Fez just didn’t let me do that.

[h1] In a world that is entirely two-dimensional, a three-dimensional object appears [/h1]

Fez begins as a simple looking 2D 8-bit pixelated platformer. Gomez (a cute, ghost-like character), lives in a 2D city in the sky with the rest of his neighbors. One day, he gets called to the top of the mountain and there he witnesses a 3D cube. Upon touching the cube a fez (hat) appears from it and lands on Gomez’s head after which the game crashes (not really, but it makes it look like it has crashed) and starts again from the beginning. Gomez starts the game again, except now he has a Fez… and the power to rotate the world by 90 degrees left or right. While Gomez gains this power and experiences the world as he had never seen it before, something bad had also happened. The object that produced the fez, is now broken and Gomez must gather its many pieces so he can restore it, otherwise the world, as he knows it will come to an end. It’s up to Gomez and his new power to explore his entire world, now from brand new perspectives, and restore the sacred cube. 

[h1] When 2D meets 3D and borrows its camera control [/h1]

It’s really hard to explain how Fez’s unique rotating mechanic work without witnessing it yourself but I will try my best to explain it. Fez is very much a 2D platformer that mostly plays like one. You will have platforms that you can jump on, things you can climb on, doors to enter, things to collect, ledges to drop on, you name it. The controls work well, you don’t have any life bar or lives, there is no game over screen, no bosses, not even a real story. So what’s the catch?

The catch is, that you wouldn’t be able to progress much in this game if it weren’t for its unique world rotating ability. Remember when Gomez found the fez? The fez game Gomez the power of 3D, however, since he is still in a 2D world, he will still view things in 2D, only he gets to rotate the camera, like you would in a 3D game, in a 90 degree angle and view it again in 2D. I know, I know, it sounds really confusing. 

So, how does this really benefit our hero on his quest? Well, a lot of platforms are unreachable and the only way to get to them is to rotate the world. Once you get to a point where you can no longer progress, it usually means that you need to look at things from a different angle. A long far away floating platform that you can’t reach will become a narrow floating platform close to you simply by rotating the camera. 

[h1] Curiosity and exploration are much more important than precision and skill [/h1]

You may think that just because Fez is a 2D platformer with a twist that you might need to be savvy with games like Mario, but that’s not really the case.There are some sections where you might have to make a precise jump or two but what this game really wants you to do is look EVERYWHERE. If the world of Fez only had one side, like all other 2D platformers, it wouldn’t be anything special, but since Fez has 4 sides, it’s important that you explore all of them. A hidden object just might be behind that wall but you won’t be able to see or collect it unless you look at things from a different angle. There might even be a whole new level or world behind that tree but you won’t be able to see it unless you rotate the world a bit. Fez is also an open world game and it’s one of those open world games where you will have to come back to places you have previously been to. 

Honestly, it’s pretty amazing how much more lively a 2D world seems when you can look at it from different angles.

[h1] Pick a path and just wing it, then do it again from a different path [/h1]

Despite being a short game, Fez is surprisingly non-linear. When you enter a new zone, you will see lots of paths that will each lead you to a different location and each of those locations will end with a cube reward. Once you find the cube, you normally get a small warp portal that will transport you back to the central zone and from there you will just go back and try a different direction. This would really confusing if it weren’t for the game’s decent map. The map will highlight places you visited and the places you completed fully, which really helps, but it will also mock you…

[h1] I hated the puzzles [/h1]

While most cubes are out in the open or hidden at the end of levels, some of them are hidden behind cryptic puzzles. Sometimes you will enter a room that seemingly has nothing but drawing and junk in it and yet you will know that something is hidden there. Such rooms require you to rotate the room a certain number of times and in certain directions (kind of like opening an old safe) in order to get a reward. I really hated these because usually you would have to really think outside of the box. One puzzle had my controller vibrate on both left and right side and I had to feel which sides I needed to rotate and in which order. Another time, I got a barcode on screen and after scanning it, my phone told me the location. Another time, there was a poster with hidden arrows I had to follow in order to get a cube. I know these might sound creative, but for someone who wanted to complete the game a 100%, I just got frustrated whenever I stumbled upon one of these rooms because often, I just didn’t get what Phil Fish (the developer) wanted me to do. Yes, I say Phil Fish because these puzzles felt, well, personal. I always felt like the game held something away from me and I had to discover it and the game would open up more, but that never happened, or at least, not during my play through. 

By definition, this should be brilliant game design and, it kind of is, yet, it frustrated me so much. I mean: “CMON PHIL, JUST LET ME GET THAT CUBE. WHY DO YOU ALWAYS WANT ME TO BANG MY HEAD AGAINST THE WALL BEFORE I FIGURE OUT WHAT EXACTLY YOU WERE THINKING”, but I digress. 

Luckily, I didn’t need to collect everything in the game in order to finish it so I just ended it as soon as I gathered enough cubes.

[h1] I’m not sure if I actually liked Fez but I really think everyone should experience it at least once [/h1]

Honestly, I am really happy I got the play a game like Fez. Even though it came out almost a decade ago, there still really isn’t anything like it out there. I would have preferred it the game didn’t have so many cryptic puzzles and if the world wasn’t so open but it was a really good experience for me and I certainly don’t regret playing and finishing it. 

I think that if you are someone who likes video games in general that you will most certainly find something to enjoy in Fez. You can argue whether or not the game is good or fun but, one thing is for sure: this game is very unique. 

Next game: Fieldrunners
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/209690/

71673055.review:
FEZ is a puzzle platformer that has the player shifting the game world around the main character, Gomez, in order to gain a different perspective on the landscape. Rotating the world around Gomez creates temporary new routes that can be accessed by climbing, jumping, etc. Rotate the world to the right, and now Gomez can reach a tree that was just out of jumping distance previously. Rotate to the right once more, and now Gomez can jump from the tree to the climbable wall that was originally out of reach. 

It's a really fun concept to mess with, and with its charming art design and few annoyances (the map being the biggest annoyance, IMO), I'd recommend fans of other puzzle platformers give this one a try.

71328624.review:
FEZ is an interesting game, that plays with environment, expectation and your ideas of what a game might be. You play as a white figure donning the titular FEZ, which gives you the ability to rotate the enviroment around you. What do I mean?

The environments are 3D, but you can only see two dimensions on screen at any given time. With the FEZ equipped you can change the 2D enviroment into a different side of the three dimensional structure.

With that out of the way, why do I not enjoy it?
It's definetly a charming puzzle game and everyone, who enjoys a good puzzle game will enjoy it... until a certain point, that is.
You see halfway through the game, FEZ decides to turn into one of those mysteriously cryptic games, that people need years to solve. The puzzles become so cryptic, in fact, that  backtracking becomes a necessary and tedious feature. This is bad, because your character isn't exactly a master of traversal.

Secondly, the game has such a lack of direction, that you can get lost very easily. Again, this is not good, seeing as your character isn't Sonic the Hedgehog. It's ok for a game to not give you directions, but all games have at the very least some semblance of where you're supposed to go: A map with a blank unexplored spot or some torches leading you in the correct direction. FEZ has none of that.

Thirdly the game requires pretty advanced knowledge of cryptography to actually be completed. This isn't stated anywhere on the games store page and feels like a scam. There are also a few QR codes to scan, so sorry for people, who don't have smartphones.

EDIT: It's been a few years, and I apologize for the harsh tone of the review. I've since grown up a bit, and I just wanted to add, that FEZ is a game made with a lot of love, and you still may enjoy it, especially if you take my warning, and already have some cryptography knowledge/are willing to spend the time to learn it to go on this game's eccentric journey.

[h3]Much Love To Phil Fish, For Trying Something New And Playing Such An Intergral Role in Indie Game History With This Release, (Even If I Didn't Like It, Personally)![/h3]

71207421.review:
TLDR: the crown jewel is the music. It's like riding on a rainbow merry-go-round bolted onto a roller coaster rail that flies through a candy-filled kaleidoscope. All without inducing you to nausea. Honestly, if you take a listen to the soundtrack on YouTube and it doesn't set off some kind of sense of wonder and delight inside you, then you're dead and you should skip this game.

Anyone who is interested in the art of video game design owes it to themselves to check out this game. It is one of the most, if not THE most highly concentrated basket of delightful innovations ever packaged into a game. 
1) The puzzle mechanics are highly imaginative. 
2) The delivery of the story of the game is... unexpected. That's all I can say without saying too much.
3) There are loads of little endorphin-yielding moments scattered around that are just delightful. Somehow Fez did all this in a genre where you would have thought there was no room left for innovation... 
4) But, the crown jewel is the music. It's like riding on a rainbow merry-go-round bolted onto a roller coaster rail that flies through a candy-filled kaleidoscope. All without inducing you to nausea. Honestly, if you take a listen to the soundtrack on YouTube and it doesn't set off some kind of sense of wonder inside you, then you're dead and you should skip this game. But if it electrifies your music sense, then you should give the devs your money and play this game. Don't bother aiming to complete the game (I did, and it's great),... just play it until you're tired of it and you will have done yourself a nice favor.

71189585.review:
Fez has a super cool concept where you 2d platform but you can "rotate" the game world to see it from another perspective. It's done super seamlessly and things work brilliantly like lining up ladders to climb up by rotating the world. The main idea of the game is to explore the map to collect cubes which open up doors leading to new areas. The music and sounds are great and the graphics fit nicely. 
The map is a bit over complicated in my opinion which made it a little tricky traversing around to where you want to go. I also found picking up and pushing things was a little bit finicky. Collect items you need to merely complete the game is not too difficult but provides a good challenge. However, after looking up online a bit about how to get some collectables in the game it seems incredibly far fetched some solutions.
Overall a well designed indie game that you can pick up for cheap, and I'd recommend it for sure.

All the weird cryptic items make me feel like a bit of a moron and I can't figure out what to do with these maps and artifacts or what these moving block puzzles are supposed to be. Which is weird because  I always had the impression that the game is supposed to be so relaxed, but the whole time I feel like I am missing huge pieces of it because my floating shape companion keeps making these remarks about things in the environment like there is going to be a big reveal about them eventually, but I never got it. And the main objective of just collect all the yellow blocks seems to clash heavily with all clandestine features that I could never get into. Heck, it took me a good while to learn how to even interpret the main map screen. For 10 clams or less, Fez is probably worth giving a try just to see if it works for you.

70863034.review:
What first appears to be a simple 2D platformer turns out to be an epic 3D puzzle game using rotating to evolve the 2D platforming. 

I spent the first level thinking "is this it?" and expecting it to get worse, then the game glitches out (it's a feature! not a glitch!) and kicks you into a twisted dimension of compelling exploration and puzzles.

It's weird, it's quirky and despite a few rough edges it's ultimately pretty fun. The collection aspect for all the achievements is a bit tedious, but those are optional.

69753801.review:
I'm very conflicted on this game. I played it a long while back, and something about it just made me mad to this day.

At first I wanted to say that if you are looking to just go through the main puzzles you'll still have a good time, but looking back - no, a lot of them are somewhat ridiculous to figure out and you might not be able to do it without help. The side puzzles, on the other hand, will *definitely* leave you clueless without a walk-through - one of them, as far as I recall, still hasn't been figured out and only a brute-forced solution is known, detailed in online forums.

FEZ definitely has some great ideas and some of them are extremely well executed. Hell, in the age of the internet, maybe some people are looking for a game that will be obtuse as all hell and enjoy seeking information on the internet to get some of the puzzles done. But if you're looking for a puzzle game to beat legitimately, without looking anything up, you have much, much better options as of right now (such as The Witness, which is absolutely genius in terms of indirect communication and puzzle design). I think this can all be boiled down into one core sentiment: I don't think FEZ respects your time in the slightest.

FEZ has its place in gaming history, with a "love-to-hate-him" developer and puzzles that took a dedicated community ages to figure out. It certainly has its merits, but as a stand-alone puzzle game to be experienced without the internet's aid, I definitely cannot recommend it.

69722702.review: Really beautiful artsyle with great sprites and pixel work, the 3D rotating mechanic, although experimented with in other games like Crush on the PSP, I feel is explored here to almost it's full potential. Although some of the puzzles are a bit frustrating, most are well designed and varied, and fulfilling to complete, and are switched up often enough so they don't get repetitive. Also the soundtrack by Disasterpeace is wonderful, and matches the games style and atmosphere almost perfectly, switching from cheerful and vibrant to somber and introspective when needed. The game can get a bit slow sometimes, and I experienced a few crashes, but nothing to completely take me out of the experience. Overall, really great, I'd recommend it to anyone that likes puzzle games or the 8-bit style of the NES.

69542586.review:
A short yet memorable puzzle platformer. It's got some lovely music, it's clear to see that a LOT of effort has been put into the world and the levels, some of which are quite unique and worth the price of admission on their own. If you enjoy exploration and uncovering rooms, secrets and secret rooms then this is a must play. Perspective shift is one of the most unique mechanics in gaming and makes for some interesting and extremely satisfying to solve puzzles. 

A lot of the secrets require understanding the Fezian language to solve which the game finds some interesting ways to help translate but unless you're really really smart and playing with a laser-sharp, microscopic focus you're unlikely to figure out on your own. Couple of puzzles are agonizingly difficult and/or the solutions are obtuse but you can find enough to complete the game easily on your own, the design is generous in that way. 

Another sticky point is the black holes that randomly spawn blocking are sometimes a challenging obstacle to work your way around but more often than not they're perfectly block your only route to progress and become an annoying design choice causing nothing but frustration, forcing you to exit and return to the area (sometimes more than once) to remove them. But aside from these nitpicks it's a beautiful game that is just joyful to explore and uncover. The soundtrack hits right in the nostalgia, instant favorite and goes a long way in elevating the experience.

I think the whole 2D character being given a 3D perspective is an analogy for us humans being 3D creatures stuck with limited perception in a 4D universe. The endings (yes there's an alternate one) might not be to everyone's liking but I found it pretty deep and thought provoking.

EDIT: Additional thoughts after 100% in NG+. I was wrong, the game is definitely not short, it's  massive. It's surprising how much is kept hidden for players that come back for a 2nd playthrough (including yet another entirely new perspective to see the environments in)

I'm hesitant to recommend this. The absolute complexity and absurd difficulty of the ways you collect some cubes and items is crazy. Honestly, I love games that require you to have a notepad handy, and use subtle clues to solve puzzles/riddles. However, this just takes it to a degree that I've not experienced before. 

 I'm recommending this because the sound design, level design, and atmosphere are incredible. Definitely a unique game that so many people clearly adore. 

 If you want to 100% this game, you will very, very, very likely need a guide. Shift+Tab-ing to see how to solve whichever ridiculous code (or finding out that you need one in the first place) takes away from the flow of the game. 

 All-in-all, I think taking the guide route is worth if, if nothing else to see the whole world this Fish guy created. It really is a work of art (emphasis on the 'work').

[b]Mode(s):[/b] Single-player

[h1][b][u]Review[/u][/b][/h1]

[b]+ Merits:[/b]

By incandescently amalgamating awe-inspiring pixelated art with luminescent puzzles, FEZ successfully establishes a well-built interrelation between nostalgia and cerebral agility. Aside from its mind-twisting multiperspective world, it presents its lingo through coruscating ciphers that require a colossal deal of perception to be interpreted. What astonishes me the most is the way its multidimensional level design encourages your imagination to utilize its bizarre physics and anomalous structures so as to proceed from point A to point B.

Gomez—the main protagonist—serves as the pivotal axis in the middle of a 3D world presented in a 2D vista. To him and his folks, it’s mythical to accept any platonic solid delineated within the Metatron’s cube—it’s just beyond their belief and dimension. The story kicks off when you cross path with Geezer—the previous Fez Guy—who will pass to you something special that allows you to experience the third dimension. Subsequently, a sentient Hypercube is revealed to summon Gomez and bequest him the Fez, but due to abstruse cosmic instability, the Hexahedron shatters into teensy cubic bits across the world.

Now, the stability of space rests on your shoulders, as the world will suffer a catastrophe unless you find those bits and integrate them back into the singular cube. With the help of Dot—your four-dimensional tesseract companion—you must navigate through the dazzling levels of the game to collect those bits using your new ability granted from the golden cube. As simple as the prime game idea seems, it is quite perplexing and is all about perception. You shift the dimensional plane 90 degrees around the vertical axis in opposite directions to find a fitting plane to your perspective to create a genuine platforming route for your character to navigate through.

Let me elaborate more: imagine two 3D columns next to each other viewed from a 2D perspective. Each column has a platform at one of their sides obscured due to dual dimensional limitations. You have to revolve the landscape 90 degrees clockwise or anti-clockwise parallel to the horizon plane to reveal those hidden platforms to navigate through the two columns. Well, that's very straightforward until the game adds optical illusions to the mix—now, things get really interesting. Illusive tricks play a twisting role when you shift to different planes in which the objective is to make a traversable path by rotating and connecting disconnected structures.

For instructions and communication, the game presents its language and tetromino signs as enigmas for you to decode. To me, I find that decrypting the ZU letters can be a conundrum, provided that English isn't your native language, as the clue presented in the scenery depends on your knowledge of holoalphabetic sentences. It's substantial to understand the ZU letters and symbols, since they play a crucial role in most of the game's riddles. FEZ is flooded with mysteries. Exploration, deep cogitation, and analysis is a must to unveil them.

The puzzles and secrets in FEZ are truly presented in an unprecedented manner; it can go as far as decompiling the executable file of the game to reveal a hidden secret in its finale. What blew me away was the way FEZ tied itself with reality by offering puzzles that require QR scanners to be solved; I didn't expect this level of idiosyncrasy. Eliminating the death penalty in case of failure is a good move by the developers to avoid any frustrations and to encourage confident experimentation.

From an artistic scope, FEZ's vivid conglomeration of 8-bit colors splendidly creates a lekker outlook. Sometimes, I had to stop for a while to admire the bewitching landscapes surrounding Gomez. By mixing classical retrospective visual style with decent old-school music, FEZ offers a sterling opportunity to experience the past in the future.

[b]- Flaws:[/b]

The lack of a story is disappointing. Adding a genuine tale would have taken this game to a completely new stage. It would have been very fulfilling to link solving puzzles with a compelling story. Don't get me wrong though, there is a story, but it's very primitive and doesn't have any excitement in it. The map layout in FEZ is discombobulating and lacks details or even labels for its locations.

[b]> Verdict:[/b]

FEZ splendidly seduces the player to fall in love with it by its brilliant puzzles, cryptic atmosphere, charming sights, and simple view-shifting mechanics. It never fails to make the player feel satisfied after passing an obstacle, unveiling a secret, or solving a riddle. The principal concept of FEZ is how it incentivizes the player to think out of the box. It also sheds light on some thought-provoking questions: What if a 3rd-dimensional being experiences the full potential of the multidimensional space? Will it allow him to achieve terminal knowledge of the universe? Or will space glitch like it did in Donnie Darko? I guess we will never know for sure...

67596381.review:
I was going to give a positive rec until I had to look up who Phil Fish was and why people hate him. Oof.

Besides that though the game is just "alright" imo. I like the 3D mechanic and though it might seem overwhelming at first, you get used to it rather quickly. And there's plenty of puzzles that use the idea rather well.

Unfortunately though that is kind of it. After the introduction (tutorial?) you're just set off to an open world-type area to collect specific cubes, until you have enough to beat the game. I was hoping there might've been a tad more progression or something to give it more of a Metroidvania feel to it but there never really was. Not that it's necessarily bad thing, but it is a little disappointing. 

Then there's the secrets. So secret that [spoiler]it uses ARG[/spoiler] you're better off just looking them up. Not that you need them to finish (iirc the base game took about 3 or 4 hours?), but if you want to complete everything it does make it more tedious.

TL;DR It's fine if you just want to play it casually (And can ignore the dev controversy) , it can get very ymmv if you want to do everything else.

67460516.review:
After it randomly wandered out of the depths of my cluttered Steam library, I realized that it's been long enough to have forgotten enough about Fez to fall in love with it again.

The brain-muscles that Fez flexes provides the satisfaction of running a mental marathon. Fez’s personal reappearance felt rather timely given my newfound interest in CAD tools over the last year. Games that toy with isometric oddities now click with the same side of my mind that makes CAD a rewarding process. Puzzles like those found in Fez may have helped lay the foundation for an education in spatial reasoning. With later perspective, the near-ARG secrets plus computer-meta gameplay/narrative elements were an early taste of a style many indie titles thrive off nowadays. This peculiar pixel platformer feels like the precursor to many other mindbending adventures. At the very least, it influenced my awareness of the powerful indie space and recently showed me the creativity it takes to reconstruct a player’s concept of normalcy.

64974953.review:
[h1]200 character summary[/h1]
Fez is a very unique and forgiving exploring puzzle platformer with a lot of secrets, sweet pixel graphics and a whole lot of dimensions. Manipulate the environment to find all the mystical cubes.

[h1]Story & Characters [b]9/10[/b][/h1]
Fez is a nice and unique story about discovering new dimensions, You play as Gomez who has lived in a 2D world for all his life, You are invited to come to the top of the town, and there a cube appears, It starts spinning and teleports you to a strange area where a cube talks to you in in a strange alphabet, You get a Fez which enables you to rotate the perspective, and by doing so you destroy the cube and crash the game, You get set back to the main menu and the game will start like it did before, Only this time you can rotate from the beginning.

Once you step outside a 4D hypercube called Dot appears stating that something is terribly wrong, The Hexahedron has been destroyed and all its fragments are scattered and without it everything will collapse. He goes on to say that you have received a gift, A great secret has been reveiled to you, You are the only one who can access these other dimensions. And with that he implies you are the only one who can save the world. Dot continues to explain some basic game mechanics and he will continue to guide you on your journey.

[h1]Gamemodes & Gameplay [b]10/10[/b][/h1]
Fez is a single player exploring game with very unique game mechanics. You play the game in 2D, but the world is 3D and you can turn everything in steps of 90 degrees. There are collectables around every corner and some are behind some true mindbending puzzles, The game has its own Alphabet, A lot of secrets where you just have to enter a button sequence in certain rooms. It is pretty tough, but it creates a very nice mixed gameplay of exploring, collecting and solving puzzles. 

You need to collect 32 Golden cubes, You can find them whole, but quite a few are in pieces of 8, Then there are 32 antimatter cubes, which are always whole but a lot harder to find, Then there are 3 red cubes which are the hardest to find. The game also has Artifacts and Treasure maps which will help you on your journey to find every cube. You travel from area to area using doors, Some are locked but you can use any key you find to unlock them. Some doors are locked behind a total number of cubes, But in general you can move pretty freely.

The game has only 1 gamemode, But after you complete the game you can start a new game plus which does not reset any progress,but does unlock a first person perspective, So you can actually look around and find more things that where hidden from you before, The nice 3D map makes it pretty clear in which areas you are missing stuff, So it is not like you are searching for a needle in a haystack, But you are certainly going to need your brain to figure out this game. The game even has a few mysteries that have not been solved untill this day, by anyone. 

The platforming is no challenge at all. The game is very relaxing, If you die or fall you respawn on the spot, It is very forgiving, The hardest part of the game are the puzzles, but you can take your time or skip it if you don't feel like it. Everything in this game feels optional, You are free to go wherever you want and do as you wish. which is pretty great.

[h1]Graphics & Soundtrack [b]9/10[/b][/h1]
It has very nice pixel graphics, Very colorful with diverse areas which are well decorated and feel very alive, It looks a bit strange in the first person perspective but that is already way more than I ever expected from a game like this. The soundtrack is great, It has a lot of variation in tunes and enhances the game with every step you take. The animations are also beautiful, It is all very geometrical, But I think it is almost an art on itself

There is a lot of geometrical art in the game, Like animated shapes that loop in on themselfes, infinite zoom illusions, etc. It uses a lot of color and somehow this fits the game just right, It is a journey about multiple dimensions, and I think this game is a good representation of how additional spacial dimensions past the third would look to us. I think the idea is great and it has been executed wonderfully.

[h1]Performance & Support [b]8/10[/b][/h1]
The game performs great, The FPS is locked which can be bad for very low spec systems. But I had no performance issues. I also had no crashes or other issues. It ran at a solid 120fps from beginning to end. If I have to make a remark, I feel the loading screens are a bit long, There is no random generation, I don't see why there is a loading screen in the first place. But it is not that long, It is just strange.

[h1]Endgame & Replayability [b]7/10[/b][/h1]
I do think all the secrets help here, There is a lot of mystery to the game. Sadly the game is pretty short, Surely collecting all collectables will take you a few hours but there is literally nothing to do once you collected all collectables next to revisit the world you already fully explored. There is a new game + but it does not offer anything new next to a camera angle, One you need to collect all collectables. It even lets you keep the collectables I do not really see it as a new game plus, More as a continue or clean up mode. You can ofcourse start a new game, But knowing the puzzles the challenge is gone. The game is amazing, But it is amazing to experience, not one to keep playing.

[h1]Conclusion [b]9/10[/b][/h1]
I really love Fez, It is a nice story, with nice pixel art and very unique game mechanics, If you like relaxing platformers with a heavy focus on exploring and solving puzzles you will love this game, and even if you don't like any of those genres, Fez truly is amazing. You will probably enjoy it. It is short, and not great in replayability, But it offers an unique experience everyone should have played in my opinion.

64092820.review: A highly inventive puzzle platformer where you rotate the world in 3D space to shift between 2D perspectives. The pixel art is gorgeous to look at, the colors are simple but rich and vibrant, the music by Disasterpeace is absolutely phenomenal (arguably one of his best work), and the worldbuilding is somewhat subtle and intriguing. There are no enemies or boss fights, and you respawn quickly, making the game pretty relaxing to play. I enjoyed the code cracking for the most part, and I thought it added to the uniqueness of the game. The only issue I had with it is that moving blocks can be incredibly difficult, because you can push or throw the blocks, but not pull them. Apart from that, it's an incredible game that everyone should play, if not for the puzzles, then for the beautiful score and aesthetic.

Finally, after years have passed, I've finished all 3 Indie Game indie games. Therefore my big, quirky, pixelated indieck is complete.

I'm happy to say I've found Fez the best of the trio and a joy to play - for the first half. In the latter, the game ceases to be a fun puzzle-platformer and (d)evolves into an obsessive, backtracking pixel-hunt with puzzles so cryptic they may as well have "internet" written on the texture. It's got its charm, but the experience shines in the first half.
Follow my advice and leave the game after completing the first ending. The rewards hereafter are slim and if you're hoping to get a less nonsensical conclusion, you're barking up the wrong tree.

63662851.review:
Time Played - 7 hrs
The game has quite a captivating art style, and the switch between 2D and 3D is perfectly executed.
The story is kinda interesting and so were the details when talking to the people in the village.
My biggest gripe with the game however is the puzzles.
I would recommend seeing a guide for those as they can be really crazy. 
Kudos to the designer for creating such complex and interesting puzzles.
But they are very difficult to understand and the game doesnt do well with its "hints" either.
This turns them into a rather annoyance that you need to get through to finish the game.
That being said the soundtrack and the artstyle of Fez are absolutely fantastic.
There are two endings to the game, one for collecting 32 cubes and the other for collecting 64.
You need to finish the game once to be able to get the 64 cube ending.

I'd rate the game higher if the complexity of the puzzles wasn't such an annoyance to me.

8/10

62284496.review:
Note: provided I am able to find a workable solution to the issue that prevented completion, I will gladly revisit this review.

This game seemed amazing. A truly unique platformer with an unmistakable, genuinely uplifting, happy vibe. Fiendishly clever while never quite becoming frustrating. Mixing equal parts motivation for completing the current area with an urge to see new places. Just enough story (cute and simple) to help the player press on to continue the journey. I'm saddened the waterfall crash monster reared it's ugly head.

Not recommended due to (apparently long-standing) stability issues. 

I can rate the portion of the game I experienced before said crash so abruptly blocked my progress: 8/10. That scoring is based on a couple criteria. The first being that the save/load screen displayed my progress through the game as ~36%. If that measurement of progress was accurate and could be taken as an indication of how much of the game I had actually seen, I could reasonably predict some level of puzzle evolution and difficulty progression. Secondly, I can only assume there is a portion of the game that provides a way to decode the Fez-ian language which I simply didn't see before the crash halted my progress. If those two criteria were true, “Fez” was tracking to be one of the best puzzle platformers I'd ever played and no doubt would have scored 9 or possibly even 10.

61906572.review:
[h1]Nothing can prepare you for what FEZ has to offer, period.[/h1]

[list]
    [*]Adventure
    [*]Platformer
    [*]Side-Scroller
    [*]Eh, Metroidvania?
    [*]Colorful
    [*]Cute AF
    [*]2D, I guess...
    [*]...hm...
[/list]
So, if you are still here... Let's get down to it:

[quote=Murderous Mammons]Spin, twist, and flip... a pervert at every turn... on this god-fricking menage I haven't banged anyone...[/quote]

You probably heard about this one, but if this review may be of use, then let's consider it otherwise. Fez is part of what could be called the Chaotic Trinity of indie forerunners (FEZ being the Chaotic-Neutral of them), back when Edmund McMillen was just another brick in the wall, Phil Fish decided to take a dip in the shark-infested waters of PC-gaming to realize the work of a lifetime. If I told you that here you play as a square-shaped kid who plays the drums and lives in a vertical village in the likes of a Ghibli film... you might think this will be your average colorful adventure platformer, right? Well, [b]WRONG[/b]!
If you are used to the afore-mentioned genres, this is [u]not[/u] your average everything there... FEZ unfolds like that quiet kid in school who gets cornered by bullies and suddenly rips them apart, and that is a major positive feature of the game. You can expect to jump a lot in these surreal landscapes, although it may not be as hard as his Chaotic-Evil cousin Super Meat Boy. Gomez greatest challenges lie in the search for fragments of the mysterious Tetragrammaton to restore order to his dimension [spoiler]under the guidance of none other than a little tesseract[/spoiler], and quite a few others just because he can, he is the guy with the FEZ after all.
Even to my addicted puzzle taste, this game is quite strong, ranging from simple decryption puzzles to ludicrous binary and hexadecimal sequences... I'm gonna be honest here, after two entire years I gave in and sought help for the last two secrets, without any regret since those solutions were so above human level, that I still believe that no one has actually solved them to this day, aside from data miners who pulled them from the source code. If that doesn't discourage your interest then you won't play anything like this elsewhere... My only gripe about it is the fact that Phil Fish hanged his keyboards after some unprecedented flaming and we might never see a sequel. Till then, we keep the old [i]Spin, twist and flip[/i].
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Feature[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
    [/tr]

        [td]Length[/td]
        [td]10-12 hours... or was it years?[/td]
    [/tr]

        [td]Jonathan Blow's second project, The Witness[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[b]TL-DR: To this day this is the only way to experience Phil Fish's unique genius.[/b]

FEZ is a stunning example of a game taking its mechanics and pushing them to the limit to bring an interesting perspective (no pun intended) to the player.

This is a game that I have been wanting to play for a while, and my friend gifted it to me over Christmas. What I can say about this game without spoiling the details is limited, but what I [i]can[/i] say is that it's one of the best puzzle games I've ever tried.

The platforming is smooth, and the puzzles can be challenging; although, due to the game's crafted mechanics, it's easy to backtrack, explore, and solve each one. The only thing I truly have against this game is that it absolutely leaves me wanting more once I completed the full 209.4% (yes, you heard me right.) 

Overall, I highly recommend getting this game, sitting down with a blanket and a notebook, and just playing. It's worth your time.

60645639.review:
I don't know exactly how to feel about this game. This is gonna be a long one.

I'm sure the main mechanic of rotating a 2D world in 3D was very novel at the time, and platforming around is very satisfying, but while I play I get this constant feeling that I'm completely lost, stumbling through the game without actually doing anything worthwhile, and overall just doing everything wrong.

So, this game is full of secrets and sprawling worlds that have multiple exits. What I did was just keep going forward, entering every door and collecting every little cube I found. I even figured out one of the easier puzzles and got an anti-cube. Though once I got enough cubes to unlock every door in the main room, it suddenly hit me that now I needed to go back. I had no idea where I was spacially, and the map was of little help because of how much information it displays, and the sheer number of nodes and secret exits. Eventually, I found the way back not because I knew where to go, but because I kept trying different ways and found it by accident.

When entering the cube doors, I found that behind them was a single room, and that confused me a lot. That cant be it, right? Before now, every room had hundreds of different places to go, and now that I got some cubes, I unlocked these tiny islands with a few more? And whats up with the cryptic language and Tetris pieces everywhere? I found a QR code in a room, finally thought I might solve one thing in this game, but even after adding the parts that were missing from it, the code was still incomplete and unreadable.

These puzzles have layers and layers of complexity to them, and when I keep going and do some more dumb platforming, I know I'll never solve anything, and that I'm experiencing the game wrong. I should be ashamed! The graphics and music and world are so beautiful though, that's a looooot of effort that went into this! I bought this on sale so I spent like what, a dollar on it? I truly cannot say if it was worth it or not. I've never played a game that made me feel so crappy and yet so engaged at once.

All that said, I recommend it purely because the experience itself is enjoyable enough, and this game truly made me think about a lot of things. All these conflicted opinions aside, this will probably be a blast for you if you're a fan of platformers, or cryptic puzzle games. As someone who thought they liked these kinds of puzzles, I'm seriously reconsidering. This game is just too big and smart for me.

60427386.review:
The whole experience is fantastic, everything about it is just right. The length is perfect, and never seems to overstay its welcome. There are a few issues, sure, most of which being difficulty related, and the game's notable tendency to be utterly cryptic with a few of it's puzzles. Yet, it is all made up for in the game's atmosphere, music, and visuals. It's a perfect indie game, in fact, I'd say it's so good, it doesn't deserve to be labeled as one. It's a wonderful experience, through and through.  My only real complaint, is the fact that the sequel was canceled years ago, and it makes me feel as though, in a way, that the experience is unfinished, too many questions are left unanswered, and the ending just feels like it leads onto something, yet, it goes nowhere. But it's worth every single dollar, at least, I think so. Give it a go, you won't be disappointed.

R.I.P. FEZ 2, Gone before it could even get started. F*** angry game reviewers, ruining great things, as they do.

It still is this wonderful world steeped in clever perspective puzzles, niceties and loveliness, together with some serious good platforming. Should someone (still) want to feed the recent boom and prepare a listicle with pixel revival survivors, FEZ is a contender for place in the top tier!

59276484.review:
This game was quite fun for me at first but near the end of the game on normal mode it became very tedious. Most puzzles have to be solved after getting an understanding a new form of language that the game made. I'm not even joking. One of the puzzles actually makes you pick up cryptic bread crumbs and a ROSETTA STONE. Of course you can just look up the answers to that puzzle online but completing this game isn't very fun when you reach the point where half of your time while playing is alt-tabbed. There were only a handful of collectibles that felt gratifying to collect (i.e QR Code and Time-Anti Cubes with the PC's internal clock) but it could barely feel good collecting them when there were twice as many annoying ones as there were fun ones.

Spoilers for end of the game: [spoiler] You can't get the "true?" ending on the first run. To get to the true ending you must collect all 64 main cubes. The first 32 are pushovers so I can understand why the game would end at that point but the first ending feels so unsatisfying. I'm not joking. It shows all your collectibles, shows the ones you're missing, and plays a drug induced hallucination scene. So after collecting 32 annoying cubes, or less if you got some extra before the first ending, you get to the true ending. In this one you watch the big cube at the beginning become complete then another crazy hallucination plays again before the credits roll. At least Gomez played the drums in first ending. This true one might be worse which is why I put some quotes on it earlier. It was just so ridiculous. [/spoiler]

Just buy it on sale and if you want another completed game for the collection but only when both criteria are met.

56865790.review: This game has its ups and downs. Don't get me wrong, it's one of the best games I've ever played. But I feel like some parts of this puzzle game aren't meant to be solved. I've been searching for years to find an actual puzzle game, after breezing through Portal 1 & 2 and The Turing Test, I came across FEZ. FEZ is the most challenging puzzle game I've seen since I picked up Mega Man. This Pixelate jigsaw puzzle had my desk full of sketches trying to figure out their puzzles. When I figured out just one meaningless puzzle, such as decoding Tetris shapes to make out "The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog", it was one of the most satisfactory feelings ever. My first run of the game (100%), I spent 4 hours figuring out the easy puzzles, with me questioning why people are complaining why it's so hard. When I finished the game, the ending confused me. I'm not going to spoil it, but it didn't all add up. It felt like I was only halfway done with the game, even though my save file said 100% complete. There was a whole 35 more puzzles that took me either minutes to figure out one, or one taking hours of making real-life 3d paper shapes to even understand how a clue helped me in a puzzle. Most of those secrets I found by myself, with dedicating my whole day to figure out one puzzle. But some puzzles seem like they don't want to be solved. The developers thought that this wasn't too hard of a game, since they already knew the answers to the puzzles. But there's one puzzle that no-one ever figured out, and brute-forced every possible combination of inputs to solve it. To this day, nobody knows why the solution is what it is. But this game changed my life, and made me think more logically and outside the box than I'd ever think would be possible. If you're dedicated to puzzle games, then I definitely recommend this to you.

55342030.review:
FEZ is an amazing puzzle game.

If you're into puzzle/adventure then this game is a must try. The game is about a cute little boy that one day becomes the holder of a fez, which gives him the ability to switch perspectives in what was first believed to be a fully 2D world. Most of the puzzles revolve around this mechanic; being able to switch perspectives in a 3D world while only having a 2D perspective. Together with the beautiful graphics and amazing soundtrack performed by Disasterpeace, (also known for their work on Hyper Light Drifter) makes for a game worth buying.

Though the game offers a little more than that. It's also filled with mysteries and more puzzles that are layers and layers deep. That makes uncovering mysteries and finding out solutions all the more satisfying as you scribble and analyze the notes that you made throughout playing the game like a mad scientist (it's highly recommended to keep some notes with you if you're planning on taking all puzzles by yourself).

The puzzles can sometimes be a little too deep/hard for it's own good. Seriously, as a consequence there is a puzzle in this game that no one ever before has properly solved. It was only solved thanks to a hint from the development team. Even with this hint, the solution was only found through a mass attempt at brute forcing a code required to solve the puzzle. A theory to the solution is out there though, one that has yet to be confirmed by the devs. Perhaps the point of this puzzle was exactly what happened; the community coming together to solve the puzzle.

Anyway, I digress. What mostly has kept me enthousiastic about this game and even made me come back to it after 5-6 years is the layers deep mysteries but also the very calming atmosphere the game has (no enemies, no stressful situations). It offers some kind of immersion, the game sucks you in. And it's fun.

Something fun for adventuring/platforming enthousiasts, a must play for puzzle enthousiasts.

55133455.review:
One of the most interesting puzzle games I've ever played. I've seen it called a 2.5D platformer, which is a completely non-informative description. You play on projections of 3-dimensional levels onto a 2-dimensional surface and you can choose projections from 4 different angles. Some puzzles are extremely challenging, but ultimately optional. It is possible to complete the whole game solving only simple puzzles. One downside is the completely useless map. It is easy to get lost.

Spoilery hint: If you are not an English speaker, you may be unfamiliar with a famous sentence containing all letters of the alphabet. Look it up. Figuring out the game's alphabet without this knowledge was fun, but also very time consuming.

53955272.review:
Now here's an innovation and a half: a platformer for [i]non[/i]-"hardcore" gamers! Who ever could'a thunk up such a thing? Why, Mr Phil Fish, that's who! 

   What's a "Phil Fish", you ask? Where's your head been the last decade or so: in a hole in a desert someplace? Shame on you. No Fez review could be complete without mentioning its ever-fascinating creator...so let's talk Fish, shall we?

   I like Phil Fish. I really, really like Phil Fish. In fact, I probably like Phil Fish more than I like his game, and I [i]do[/i] like Fez: even if I've started it twice now, just to lose interest part-way through each time (more [i]my[/i] fault than the game's, methinks). It's certainly not my usual kind of game - it's non-violent, for starters - but if ever there was a shameless labour of love, this would be it. [i]So[/i] much love from Mr Phil Fish; yet so much hate [i]for[/i] Mr Phil Fish, from so much of the so-called gaming "community". 

   Actually, that's rather cynical of me. I shouldn't put the word "community" in inverted commas, because communities [i]always[/i] have their own peculiar forms of witch-burning, don't they? And Phil, in the eyes of many, became a witch. Oh, how they hated Phil Fish, boys and girls. But why? [i]Why[/i] did the gamers come to hate Phil Fish so much, oh humble reader?

   Anyone who's watched Indie Game: The Movie as many times as I have - which is a lot! - will know that Phil Fish is a man who wears his heart on his sleeve. Whether his heart is in the mood to embrace other hearts, or wants to "cold-blooded f*cking murder" all other hearts in the room...there it is, bleeding all over his shirt. And we gamers - and indeed, most human beings on the planet - not only hate and despise people who wear their hearts on their sleeves, but feel a need to BURN THEM like THE EVIL WITCHES THAT THEY ARE. How dare someone announce a game, get us all hot and bothered, then take [i]years[/i] to finesse it into a quality product that shedloads of people can now enjoy? The cheek of it.

   Shame on you, Phil Fish. Shame on you. And shame on Renaud for helping you take so many years to finish it. Why, a mega-corporation with a design and programming team of a hundred people could easily have pumped out a game in [i]four-fifths[/i] of the time it took the two of you to make one lousy, if lovingly-rendered, little pixel game. Shame on you for not employing another ninety-eight people to help you get this game out quicker to the jaded, frothy-mouthed masses of fat, bearded fan-boys in Gamer-land (like me). I hope you both writhe on [i]flaming stakes[/i] for your crimes against humanity.

   You let down every single gamer-boy and gamer-gal on the planet who couldn't wait an extra couple of years for you to finish your painstakingly detailed retro tribute to all the games you grew up loving. Your heartfelt homage to games from the 1980s became hopelessly dated in the interminable wait from 2007 through to the eventual release date in 2012. Thanks to you guys, lonely bedroom warriors had to find [i]other stuff[/i] to do in those intervening years, like, erm...playing other video games, I guess. The [i]nerve[/i] of you guys!

   Damn you both to Eternal Damnation for what you did to those people. And damn you doubly, Phil Fish, for then refusing to bring out a Fez 2 to appease those very same scorned gamers who decided to forgive your sins against humanity after the game eventually got released and turned out to be pretty good after all. Thanks to you, they have nothing to look forward to or express anger towards, because the world really is a very sad and Fez-less place now that you, Mr Phil Fish, selfish so-and-so that you are, have decided that you have no desire to make another Fez game. Surely you aren't labouring under the misapprehension that your life is one to be lived by and for [i]yourself[/i], as opposed to being born to serve the whims of these far superior, couch-clad beings?

   YOU, SIR PHIL FISH, ARE A DISGRACE TO HUMANITY.

   ...

   Oh yeah, the game. It's pretty good, actually. Charming, unique, with a very groovy world-rotating mechanic that cleverly comments on the way that some people see the world as a far more limited place than the three-dimensional one that lies just outside their front door.

   Waitaminute...Phil Fish...you mischief-making gremlin, you! You weren't making a comment about stereotypical [i]gamers[/i], were you, Phil Fish? You cheeky, clever man! There we were, deriding you all along, when the joke was actually on [i]us[/i]! Now all we need to do is watch a film like Zero Charisma, and we would all implode from the self-revelation that maybe, just maybe, we're [i]not[/i] the impeccable, irreproachable creatures we all previously envisioned ourselves as. Maybe, deep down inside, we're just like you, Phil Fish. Flawed. [i]Human[/i]. Say it ain't so, Mr Phil Fish. Say it ain't so...

   Oh, and by-the-by, I will endeavour to finish this game some day. It just hasn't been the right "timing" for me, but I'm sure that day will come. [i]One[/i] day. But that shouldn't stop you from enjoying it right now, if it sounds like something you're currently in the mood for.

Verdict: 8.5/10.

(PS If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my two Curator pages: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9284586-ReviewsJustfortheHELLofit/​
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10868048-Truly-Horrible-Horror-Games/?appid=398210​
Cheers!)

53918157.review:
A mind blowing experience both times I've played through it. While I don't envy the time/effort needed for such in-depth, obsessive world building (complete with unknown alien language that you have to figure out on your own), it creates a magical sense of adventure, mystery, and a mixture of the familiar and the wildly unknown that is intoxicating.

Oh, and it's an awesomely crafted puzzle platformer too. Plus the phenomenal score (the most beautifully evocative I've ever heard in a game). Plus the art-game touches (honestly, I prefer the mindf*** of the non-completionist ending) that are balanced well with easy to grasp mechanics and simply fun gameplay. Plus that character design.

Without question, one of the best games I've ever played.

53825801.review: Fez is overly complicated, way too mysterious, and much too clever for its own good – and this is exactly what makes it such a special game. It’s a game doesn’t want to be beaten right away; it hopes that these puzzles will take you years, or even a lifetime, to figure out, and that you’ll obsessively work to decode all its cyphers and buried secrets. Sometimes you'll just be way too frustrated and you'll look up a puzzle in a guide, and you'll think to yourself, "Ok, what the hell, I would never have gotten that in a million years." If you think that sounds pretty frustrating, I agree, but I also think that there's a place for weird and uncompromising and frustratingly secretive games like this. It's a game that invites you to rage at it, talk about it, discuss solutions with other players, make your own little maps, scrawl notes to yourself on scrap paper, and to put it away in annoyance until you pick it back up a couple of years later and give it another go. If that sounds like miserable time to you, I don't blame you, and Fez absolutely won't be for everyone - but if you're down for something different, it's a unique experience that is more than worth the asking price.

Exploring the community that grew around solving the more difficult aspects of the game, in order to 209.4% it, is like a game in and of itself. Though a puzzler is often only satisfying if the solution is found through one's own ingenuity some of the solutions in fez are essentially impossible without blind luck, or obsessive perseverance, so resorting to a walkthrough is perfectly reasonable, and can be fun just to see how ridiculous the more roundabout solutions are. 52632536.review:
Fez is a fun, treasure-hunting game across a multitude of beautiful environments where the main mechanic is to change perspective by rotating the environment like 4 sides of a cube. Changing perspective allows you to use the terrain to get to places you wouldn't be able to get to normally - it's amazing how well they implemented this. It's presented very simply where you basically jump in and get started, story is minimal and it's all about the fantastic exploration where your curiosity drives you forward.

The map is pretty big with a bunch of rooms that connect to each other in a particular layout, and you can only tell if you've collected everything in a room if it shows up as gold on the map. Each room is unique and it is a blast to explore every room and attempt to 100% it.

With that being said, the game is virtually non-100%able if you don't use a guide for certain rooms, as the game features it's own cryptic language to decipher and rooms that any regular person would not figure out in any timely kind of manner. This was a big turn-off for me since I don't like to spoil myself or use guides, but when I learned what you needed to do, I felt no shame since the game was not meant for a NORMAL person to 100% (the save file actually tracks to around 214%, this is what I'm referring to by 100%).

With all that said, I still recommend it as you can get it for very cheap, and it was still an excellent, UNIQUE experience that I'm glad to have experienced. So much so that a FEZ 2 was highly demanded but due to external issues will not be happening.

51905359.review:
FEZ is a puzzle platformer that has extremely deep puzzles for you to solve. While it may look that the game is simple, under that facade is a huge number of problems that, let's face it, you probably couldn't solve unless you poured... 10? 20? 50? Even 100 hours into the game, without guides? And players are *still* wondering if there is anything more to the game, if it goes even deeper. My bet is that it probably is.

Even then, just get this game and play it. I promise that there aren't as many big brain puzzles as you would think, and it is finishable with only sheer exploration. Fun exploration I might add.
